column1: Over 60,000 lives claimed by COVID-19 in U.S. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a tally some models predicted for late
column6:
Amid a bleak financial outlook in which the U.S. economy saw its steepest drop since the Great Recession, a mix of both optimism and caution blanketed the country on Wednesday as officials weighed responses to the COVID-19 pandemic.
In New York, Gov. Andrew Cuomo noted that the death rate has declined in recent days but is still disturbingly high. At least 330 people died across New York State on Tuesday, Cuomo said, down from 335 and 337 the previous days.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You see the decline has been slow at best, and [the toll is] still disgustingly high,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Cuomo said during a news conference at the state Capitol building in Albany.
World & Nation
With mounting COVID-19 deaths, New York shortens the amount of time it will hold unclaimed remains before burying them in the cityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s public cemetery.
Cuomo said he will sign an executive order on Wednesday allowing hospitals in some counties in upstate New York to begin elective surgeries again. Like governors nationwide, Cuomo inrecent days has announced roachto reopening. The state, which has been the U.S. epicenter has a stay-at-home order that is set to expire May 15, but it could be extended.
Most of the deaths have been in New York City, where police late Tuesday broke up a massive funeral in Brooklyn for a rabbi. Nearly 2,500 Orthodox Jewish community members attended the funeral.
New York Mayor Bill de Blasio called the large gathering ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½unacceptable.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½When I heard, I went there myself to ensure the crowd was dispersed. And what I saw WILL NOT be tolerated so long as we are fighting the Coronavirus,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said on Twitter. De Blasio later said he was showing ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½tough loveï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ in expressing anger over the situation.
Meanwhile, in neighboring New Jersey, Gov. Phil Murphy announced he will reopen all state parks and golf courses on May 2. He said social distancing will still be required for the foreseeable future.
The death toll from COVID-19 approached 61,000 in the United States on Wednesday, and confirmed cases sns Hopkins University. Some models had suggested the U.S. would not reach this milestone until late summer. The shuttering of businesses nationwide ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ restaurants, gyms, retail ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ has led the U.S. economy toshrink 4.8%in the first quarter.
Elsewhere across the country on Wednesday, governors continued to assess conditions in their states and craft plans for reopening businesses.
Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said church services with limited capacities could resume in early May. Several pastors across the country have defied stay-at-home orders, preaching before packed churches.
In Tennessee, retail shops are allowed to reopen at 50% capacity. Some businesses in Texas began allowing workers to return after Gov. Greg Abbott announced this week that on Friday restaurants could reopen at 25% capacity.
In many of these states, the racial disparities in terms of who contracts the virus and dies have been stark. A lack of access to quality healthcare, among other things, has led to higher rates of infection munities across the country.
A report released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed that in Georgia, where businesses have almost fully reopened in recent days to the dismay of health officials, nearly 80% of those hospitalized with COVID-19 were black.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Black patients were disproportionately represented among hospitalized patients, reflecting greater severity of COVID-19 among this population,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ wrote researchers at the CDC, which is based in Atlanta.
On Wednesday, Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards, a Democrat, met with President Trump at the White House. Heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the latest governor to meet with Trump ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½on Tuesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, last week Cuomo ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and discuss paths forward in the pandemic.
During the meeting with Bel Edwards, Trump said that social distancing guidelines would be ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½fading outï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ in the weeks and months ahead. Earlier in the week, one of his top advisors on the coronavirus task force, Dr. Deborah Birx, said social di summer.
Edwards extended his stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s stay-at-home order, which was set to expire in the days ahead, to mid-May.
Meanwhile, DeSantis, back in Florida, announced that on Monday  portions of the state would see an eased stay-at-home order. Restaurants and retail shops would reopen at 25% capacity.
But, DeSantis said, three of the most populous counties in the state ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ would stay under a strict order for several more weeks to help slow the spread of the virus. Florida has seen 32,800 confirmed virus cases and at least 1,170 deaths.
DeSantis said the state was taking a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½very slow and methodical approach.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a light at the end of the tunnel,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.

column1: Newsletter:ï¿½ï¿½The plan to reopen Califo
column6:
Gov. Gavin Newsom has introduced a phased plan for getting California going again, but when that happens isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t clear.
The Plan to Reopen California
Faced with millions of people out of work, some local officials wanting to ease the coronavirus lockdown, andrising criticismï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ but with some areas, including Los Angeles County, still struggling to get a handle on the public health crisis ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ California Gov.Gavin Newsomhas unveileda four-phase planto reopen the state.
Businesses seen as presenting less risk of spreading the coronavirus could open in the near future: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We believe we are weeks, not months, away from making meaningful modificationsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ in the current restrictions, he said. The academic year for K-12 studentscould start in late July or early August.
But, notably, Newsomï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s announcementdid not come with a guaranteed timetable or a number of details. He said that while current public health indicators such as hospitalizations and testing capacity look promising,  toward slowing the spread of the virus.
Meanwhile, L.A. County continues to be the coronavirus epicenter of California, having surpassed 1,000 deaths. The county represents about a quarter of the state population but about half of all COVID-19 hospitalizations. Officials say the restrictions on movements must continue for now, but theyare developing a plan to ease the Safer at Home order, which is set to expire May 15.
Start your day right
Sign up for Essential California for the L.A. Times biggest news, features and recommendations in your inbox six days a week.
You may occasionally receive promotional content from the Los Angeles Times.
No Longer Ready for Prime Time?
President Trumpï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s public musing last week that doctors should consider injecting household disinfectant ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a known poison ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ into coronavirus patients set off a political shockwave so severe that aides and alliesscrambled to rein in his prime-time nightly news conferences.
For the first time since mid-March, Trump took am the podium over the weekend. On Sunday, he tweeted that the appearances were ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½not worth the time & effort.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ But the former reality TV star has refused to leave the stage, even as polls show his approval rating has fallen in recent weeks.
On Tuesday, as U.S. deaths from COVID-19 topped 58,000 ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ exceeding the number of American fatalitiesduring the entire Vietnam Warï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and confirmed cases exceeded 1 million, Trump appeared before the cameras twice during the day, for 90 minutes total. He still managed to berate reporters, air familiar grievances and shower himself with praise.
An Unlikely Lab for Testing
When the coronavirus hit, L.A. County faced a testing crisis: Officials had only one test processing machine at a laboratory in Downey and had little hope of getting help from the federal government.
So they turned to a brand-new Silicon Valley start-up, Curative-Korva, with a novel approach that said it could provide a large number ofdrive-through testsvery quickly, by allowingown mouths after coughing. Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not the method preferred by the Food and Drug Administration, which recommends an uncomfortable swabbing deep inside the nose by a professional.
This makes Los Angeles Countyan unlikely laboratory for COVID-19 testing. If it works, it could usher in a much more streamlined form of testing across the country. If itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s less accurate than other approaches, it could mean some of the measurements tracking the extent of the outbreak are muddier than previously known.
More Top Coronavirus Headlines
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Trump signed an executive order that compelsslaughterhousesto remain open,setting up a showdownbetween the giant companies that produce meat and the unions and activists who want to protect workers in a pandemic.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Two weeks after other states started sending checks, California has begun acceptingunemployment benefit claimsfrom millions of independent contractors, gig workers and the self-employed, but many said online glitchesprevented them from filing ape high hopes forantibody tests, but those high hopes are running smack intothe roadblocks of reality.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Hollywoodis figuring out how to start rolling again, andlots of interested parties have ideason how to make that happen.
Somethingï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s in the Air
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s been hailed as a silver lining of the coronavirus lockdown: With fewer cars on the road,air qualityhas improved, bringing clearer skies to cities across the world, including L.A., which had its longest streak of good air days in decades.
But that streak is over, after a recent heat wave generated unhealthy smog levels across Southern California. Air quality officials are predicting more bad air days to come, even with public health restrictions in effect, as the region enters a hotter, drier time of year.
Still, scientists and regulators saythe situation offers an unintended glimpseat what the nationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s smoggiest region could be like with more electric vehicles.
The L.A. Times is starting a newsletter exploring climate change, enerign up forBoiling Pointfor the latest on everything from water wars to wildfires to ways to live more sustainably. It begins May 7.

column1: Many states scrambling to update hurricane plans for virus
column6:
Officials across the South are still scrambling to adjust their hurricane plans to the coronavirus. The big unknown: Where will people fleeing storms go?
The Associated Press surveyed more than 70 counties and states from Texas to Virginia and found that more than 60% of coastal counties said as of late May they were still solidifying plans for public hurricane shelters. Theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re also altering preparations for dealing with the sick and elderly, protective equipment and cleanup costs.
In Georgiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s McIntosh County, south of Savannah, Emergency Management Agency Director Ty Poppell said evacuations during the pandemic would be a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½nightmare.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ He worried about social distancing at shelters and on buses used to get people out.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½d love to be able to tell you weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve got that answered right now,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Poppell said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a work in progress.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Hurricane season officially starts Monday, though tropical storms Arthur and Bertha arrived earlthing that we do will be affected in one way or another, big and/or small, by COVID-19,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Florida Emergency Management Director Jared Moskowitz said.
Many counties are taking federal advice and hope to use hotels as smaller-scale shelters. Others plan to use additional areas of schools besides just the gymnasiums. Still others, especially in Louisiana, plan for big shelters with more social distancing.
Officials emphasize that shelters are a last resort and urge people to stay with friends or in hotels. But massive unemployment is making the expense of hotels less feasible.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Our biggest change to our hurricane plan is sheltering. How are we going to shelter those that have to evacuate? How are we going to shelter those that are positive-COVID patients? There are multiple ideas that we are considering right now,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Mississippi Emergency Management Agency Director Greg Michel said.
During tornadoes in April, the state used hotels as shelters, which was good practice for hurricane season, hees surveyed said they were still figuring out shelters.
Although that may sound worrisome, it could be beneficial because emergency managers need to update plans as the pandemic changes, said University of South Carolina disaster expert Susan Cutter.
But Brad Kieserman, an American Red Cross executive, sounded a cautionary note.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Disasters are not going to stop for COVID-19,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he told reporters earlier in May. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Hope is not a plan. And weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve got to plan for tens of thousands of people to evacuate in the face of hurricanes and wildfires and other disasters.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Shelters were the most mentioned worry in the survey, but comfort levels with other aspects of hurricane preparations varied, reflecting the difference in how states plan for disasters. Having enough staff for shelters is a persistent problem locally and nationally, said Jeff Goldberg, emergency management chief for Floridaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Walton County.
Protective equipment is the biggest shortfall in several North Carolina with counties often waiting for federal reimbursement. Handling nursing homes, hospitals and COVID-19 patients ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½is one of the most difficult challenges and would require a larger state response,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Jeffrey Johnson, fire chief in Newport News, Va.
Other places downplayed concerns. Orleans Parish, where 2005ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Hurricane Katrina ravaged New Orleans, has added social distancing and protective equipment to a 10-year-old plan thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s otherwise ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½essentially unchanged. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a good plan,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Collin Arnold, head of the cityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s emergency preparedness office.
A year ago, officials in North Carolinaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Beaufort County would have rated their readiness going into hurricane season at a 95 on a 0-to-100 scale. With the virus, thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s down to 75. Brad Baker, emergency management director of Floridaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Santa Rosa County, gave the same numbers ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½because thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a lot of unknowns with COVID.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In Texasï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Nueces Cong into hurricane season last year. Now, itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s below 80, emergency management coordinator Melissa Munguia said. If another Harvey brings 50 inches of rain, she said, the same reinforcements wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t arrive because ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½everybodyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s been working their personnel for many hours for over 100 days.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Florida officials were far more upbeat.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½While COVID-19 complicates things and you have to plan around [it], I think Florida is as prepared as ever before in response to a hurricane,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Moskowitz, the state emergency management chief.
In Louisiana, disaster officials said they were used to ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½overlapping emergencies, and you just have to plow through.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
They anticipate making adjustments, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½but itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s hard to pin down what those changes will be,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Mike Steele, spokesman for the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s emergency preparedness office. By August and September, typically the height of Louisianaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s hurricane season, the number of infectionane is hard, and the coronavirus ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½is going to make it a little bit more difficult,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Federal Emergency Management Agency Director Pete Gaynor told reporters in May. But he said FEMA had hired 500 people since March and had a record $80 billion in its disaster fund.
Vice President Mike Pence told President Trump on Thursday that the federal government would ensure state and local authorities could handle hurricanes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Bottom line, Mr. President, weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re ready.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Academics who study disasters arenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t so sure.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t think [federal officials] are doing the job they should be doing. I worry about their ability to handle a very large hurricane in addition to COVID-19,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Cutter, of the University of South Carolina.
She and others said mixed messages on the coronavirus meant some people werenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t believing what theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re hearing from Washington in an emergency.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I think our lives are in danger now because we donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t trumy and patchy federal responses to three 2017 hurricanes, people should prepare for little help from the government, Virginia Commonwealth University emergency preparedness professor Hans-Louis Charles said.
Experts also worry that it could take longer to return to normal after a hurricane. Search and rescue teams, utility workers who restore power lines and volunteers who help clean up may be slowed or not respond at all because of concerns over virus exposure, experts said. That and other issues may mean a storm that in the past caused $12 billion in insured damage, like 2018ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Hurricane Michael, may cost 20% more, catastrophic-risk modeler Karen Clark said.
Although many officials are still trying to figure out shelters, they said if people were told to evacuate in a hurricane, residents must go. Storm surge is more dangerous than the coronavirus, officials said.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½In hurricane season, we canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have mixed messages. If you live in an evacuation zone, your plan is to evacuate if orderel officials,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ former FEMA director Craig Fugate said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This message will not change, COVID or no COVID.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

column1: California surpasses 4,000 coronavirus-related deaths, with L.A. County hardest hit
column6:
Los Angeles County reported 50 additional coronavirus-related deaths Friday, bringing Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s total to more than 4,000 ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a somber milestone in the months-long pandemic that has ravaged communities and local economies. More than half of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s deaths have occurred inL.A. County.

The news came after the county received permission from the state to reopen hair salons and barbershops and allow in-person dining.
The relaxed restrictions do not necessarily mean business as usual, though. County public health officials are expected to announce restrictions on operations, including a 60% capacity limit for restaurants.

California
L.A. County, the epicenter of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s coronavirus outbreak, canson dining and resume services at hairstyling shops.

ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We will direct local health officials to put a dimmer switch on,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said Friday. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We are not mandating a pace for opening.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Dr. Christina Ghaly, director of health services for L.A. County, said Friday that although the numbers of local cases are flattening, the county may see a new upward curve as more businesses reopen and chances of transmission increase. But that wouldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t necessarily mean that the county would have to backtrack.

ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½If in fact the state determines that thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a cause of concern, what they really are doing is offering technical support,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Ferrea county to rescind its eased restrictions but would instead try to understand what is driving an increase in numbers to properly assist.
The death toll in the state ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ which now stands at 4,051 ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ remains much lower than in the coronavirus hot spots of Michigan, New Jersey and New York. But officials have said that though other metrics such as hospitalizations and new confirmed cases offer signs of significant progress, deaths in California remain a major concern.
Los Angeles County remains the center of the outbreak in California, with a total of 2,294 COVID-19 deaths. The number of confirmed cases in L.A. Countyrepresents about half of all California cases.
California
Los Angeles County announced Tuesday that it will align with Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s latest guidelines to allow faith-based services, in-store shopping at low-risk retail stores, drive-in movies and other recreational activities. Beauty salons will still be closed.
Earlier this week, the county allowed shopping malls and churches tct social distancing and safety rules.
With the city of Los Angeles, Mayor Eric Garcetti on Friday announced that restaurants, barbershops and hair salons were permitted to reopen effective immediately, with stylists limited to one customer at a time with everyone required to wear masks.
Restaurants were also allowed to reopen and can apply with the city to open their sidewalks and private parking lots to outdoor dining as well, the mayor said. Houses of worship can fill up to 25% capacity or 100 people, whichever is lower, as long as social distancing guidelines are met and congregants wear masks, Garcetti said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re entering a new phase of this crisis and we feel comfortable that weï¿½ï¿½tcan begin reopening parts of our economy,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Breed said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½But that is not to say that this virus doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t continue to threaten our city.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
San Franciscoï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s planincludes three phases.
In addition to allowing outdoor dining and restricted in-store retail service by June 15, the city plans to permit private household indoor services, religious services and ceremonies, outdoor exercise classes, sports games with no spectators, and nonemergency medical appointments.
The second phase would start on July 13, when restaurants could reopen for indoor dining, hair salons and barbershops could reopen, and real estate open houses could resume by appointment only.

In the final phase ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the date of which has yet to be determined ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the city would reopen concert venues, nightclubs, festivals and hotels for tourism.
City officials cautioned t San Francisco continued to make progress in slowing the spread of COVID-19.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We want to lock in those gains, and we want to move forward in a way that is going to be safe for everybody,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said San Francisco County Health Officer Dr. Tomï¿½ï¿½s Aragï¿½ï¿½n during an online forum with the mayor Friday.
During the 1918 flu pandemic, Aragï¿½ï¿½n said, the places that reopened slowly did better economically because they did not have large second waves of infection.
He added that health officers and the cityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s health department will soon release new guidelines about how families from different households might safely interact. The guidelines would focus on social distancing, face coverings, hand washing and the need to be tested first if a person felt ill, he said.
But at the same time,  Newsom has routinely cautioned that even with businesses across the state starting to reopen, the threat of the coronavirus is not over.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This virus has not gone away,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the governor said earlesia. Letï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not forget why weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re in this position in the first place. Letï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not be naive about the virulence of this disease.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

column1: Citing ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½existential threat,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ House climate action plan has a big focus o
column6:
California and other U.S. states face ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½an existential threatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ from climate change that requires a robust government response, a House select committee statedin a 538-page action plan Tuesday.
The ambitious plan, authored by Congressï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ first-ever committee dedicated exclusively to climate change, could be a framework for addressing the planetï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s warming, depending on the outcomes of the November election.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Individuals and the private sector cannot achieve unprecedented pollution reductions on their own,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the House Select Committee on the Climate Crisis said in its report. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Only through a coordinated national response can the United States deliver the urgent and systemic changes needed to avert the worst consequences of climate change.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The report calls for 12 pillars of action, including reducing carbon pollution, making communities more resilient to the impacts of climate change and building a more equitable energy economy. Specific targets include and delivering $8 trillion in health and climate benefits.
May 2020 tied forthe highest global May temperaturesince record-keeping began 141 years ago, according to the NOAA. It also exceeded the highest monthly average for atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations.
The planï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s emphasis on establishing pollution reduction targets ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ including substantial reductions in net U.S. greenhouse gas emissions ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ aims to reverse or at least mitigate these trends, but it is unlikely to have any immediate impact since it would need to be embraced by the Republican-led Senate and President Trump, who has called climate changea hoaxand appointed skeptics to top environment and energy posts.
In the past, Republicans have been critical of Democratic action plans such asthe New Green Deal, introduced by Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York and Sen. Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts, arguing such blueprints will hurt the U.S. economy and sectors dependent on inexpensive energy sources.
In a joint stsday, Republicans on the committee said they were disappointed the planï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s rollout did not include an ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½amendment process where all committee members could vote on recommendations to report to Congress,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and argued that the country should look toward renewable energy as a supplement to, not a replacement for, oil and gas.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Smart climate policy must seek ways to address emissions, while protecting the economic and geopolitical value of our natural resources,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ they wrote.
But Democrats see the action plan as a way to elevate environmental issues as they try to hold the House and take back in the Senate and White House in the coming election.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Against this backdrop, one may wonder why Select Committee Democrats would choose to release this report with recommendations to solve the climate crisis,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the preface reads. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We cannot wait.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The report also hits close to home: it calls for the creation of ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½clean energyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ jobs, a field inue to the coronavirus pandemic.
Politics
Long and intense heat waves are nothing new in Southern California and the Southwest, but amid COVID-19, public health experts are warning they could become deadlier for people self-isolating in homes they canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t keep cool.
It recommends timely action on several California-introduced climate bills, including theWildfire Defense Act, which empowers local communities to implement wildfire prevention and mitigation methods, and the West Coast Ocean Protection Act, which prohibits the Interior Department from issuing oil and gas leases off the coast of California, Oregon or Washington. Three of the committeeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s nine Democratic members hail from California.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Our report will build on the progress in California with bold action and legislation,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said committee member Rep. Mike Levin (D-San Juan Capistrano), ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½while also putting Congress on a path to ensure our state has a federal partner that truly wants to address the climate crisis.ï¿½inte action plan points to California as a model for other states to follow: it lauds Gov. Jerry Brownï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s 2018 legislation requiring100% zero-carbon electric generationby 2045, and identifies California as the ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½strongest exampleï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ of state-authorized funding for public participation in natural gas proceedings. It also touts the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s stance on vehicle emissions and recommends that Congress ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½allow all states to adopt and enforce Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s motor vehicle emission standards.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
But the report also points to California as a case study for the negative impacts of climate change. The stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½saging electric sectorï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ whose equipment malfunctions constitute the third leading cause of wildfires ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ is vulnerable to outages caused by hotter, drier conditions. The plan calls for a comprehensive federal strategy to help grid operators and utilities such as  PG&E plan for and prevent power interruptions in the face of increasing extreme weather eventur newsletter exploring climate change, energy and the environment, and become part of the conversation ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and the solution.

As Braun spoke, he was holding a bottle of hand sanitizer and wearing a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½California Strongï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ mask as he sat in his backyard overlooking the Pacific Ocean. column1: After 250 years, Esselen Tribe regains a piece of its ancestral homeland
column6:
After 250 years, theEsselen Tribe of Monterey Countyis returning home.
A $4.5-million land deal, brokered by Portland-based environmental groupWestern Rivers Conservancy, will return a 1,199-acre parcel of wilderness along the Little Sur River to the tribe in the name of conservation and cultural resilience.
The transfer will mark the first land returned to the Esselen since they were displaced centuries ago.
In 1770, Spanish colonists gathered up the Esselen, whom they considered ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½neophytes and heathens,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Tribal Chairman Tom Little Bear Nason, and forced them to convert to Catholicism.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This is the center of our universe,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Nason said of the land. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We are so incredibly empowered to return to the actual birthplace of our people.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Although the parcel represents only a small fraction of the tribeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s original ancestral territory, Nason said it will be a refuge after years of alienation.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Elders always foretold that we would reconnect to our ancesophecy has been fulfilled.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The property faces Pico Blanco, a stately, mossy mountain in the Santa Lucia range considered an essential part of the tribeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s origin story. But with old-growth trees, rolling hills of wildflowers and a deep river canyon, the land transfer is as much about conservation as it is about environmental justice.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Our motivation is rivers and the critters that depend on them,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Sue Doroff, president and co-founder of Western Rivers Conservancy. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½To combine these conservation and recreation accomplishments with repatriating the land to the tribe ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ideal.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The parcel was purchased with a grant provided by theCalifornia Natural Resources Agency. The previous owner was a Swedish family who initially went under contract with another buyer, Doroff said. Whenthe Soberanes fireswept through the area in 2016, the buyer was scared off and Western Rivers Conservancy was able to move in.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½If the property was purchased byDoroff said, noting that would have been a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½real lossï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ because the property links U.S. Forest Service land on the coast to the main body of Los Padres National Forest.
With one of the last viable streams for summer steelhead on the Central California coast, the land is also part of the Big Sur stronghold for the threatened fish. And since its ancient redwoods ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ some of the southernmost in the world ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ could serve as a nursery for redwood seeds, it may prove crucial for climate change adaptation.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This property rings all the bells for fish, for wildlife,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Doroff said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½And the fact that the Esselen will be the land managers and long-term stewards of this property, and its owners, is just a bonus, and super exciting.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When Western Rivers Conservancy first went under contract on the property in 2015, the original plan was to transfer it to the Forest Service. But locals objected, citing concerns about increased traffic, tourism and fire danger.
Thatysselen, who agreed to manage the land with both the community and conservation in mind. Nason said the tribe plans to build altars, a ceremonial dance house and a bear dance lodge. They also hope to rebury ancestors whose burial sites were disturbed by development.
Because the Esselen are not a federally recognized tribe, the property will be held by the tribeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s 501(c)(3) organization, Doroff said. The tribal members will own it in fee, which means it is legally theirs, although they are obligated to follow a management plan to ensure its longevity.
That the transfer happened in the midst of a pandemic is significant, Doroff added, in that it is a reminder that these kinds of issues canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t fall by the wayside.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We all have to pay attention to the things that we love and the places that we care about,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This work must go on, because if it doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t, these opportunities will be lost forever.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

column1: Ron Howardï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Rebuilding Paradiseï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ is a stirring portrait of a town devastate
column6:
The sound of wind is rarely as sinister as it is at the beginning of ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Rebuilding Paradise,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Ron Howardï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sharrowing and heartrending new documentary. The loud, 40-mph gusts we hear are a grim omen, and they soon merge with other noises ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ anxious radio chatter, screaming sirens, the crackle of flames, the pop-pop of exploding tires ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ to form a chorus of fast-mounting dread. Through it all we hear a succession of human voices, trying to remain steady but finally abandoning any pretense of calm: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Please, we need your help, Lord,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a woman prays. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m scared,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ another sobs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m scared.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
You will share her fear. These opening moments return us to Nov. 8, 2018, the day the Camp fire,the deadliest wildfire in California history, destroyed the Butte County town of Paradise. The on-the-ground footage we see is as awful as what we hear: As flames lick at driveways and engulf crumbling buildings, as embers rain down on fg that the entire world has turned black and orange. But all is not lost: Suddenly weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re in a car that passes through a thick cloud of smoke and ash and then emerges, miraculously, into daylight on the other side. A clear blue sky has never looked so welcome.
That moment of hope is fleeting but important. Filmed over the year that followed the deadly blaze, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Rebuilding Paradiseï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ is about redemption as well as destruction, which you might guess from both the title and Howardï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s well-known affinity for uplift. But while the filmmaker keeps his eyes peeled for every possible shred of good news in the wake of disaster, he has little interest in peddling easy inspiration; the stakes are too colossal, the devastation too raw. When the Camp fire swept through Paradise, it left 85 people dead, destroyed 14,000 homes and displaced tens of thousands of residents. For many of them, there was simply no going back. But others, some of them profiled in this movie, saw no choice but to return hose historic small towns much idealized for their beauty, close-knit community and idyllic way of life, Paradise commanded intense loyalty among those who called it home. But apart for some brief early footage, Howard doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t spend a lot of time delving into the past or showing us the town as it once existed. Staying firmly in the present tense, he and his camera crew spend a lot of time following their subjects, some of whom have temporarily relocated to trailer homes in nearby Chico.
A few high schoolers, returning to what used to be their houses, marvel at metal bed frames and other abandoned possessions that have burned almost beyond recognition. A man points out buildings, including a hospital, that no longer exist. In effect, the filmmakers make us imagine what Paradise used to be by sifting through the wreckage of what it has become.
They also adopt the familiar strategy of telling a sweeping, panoramic story through a handful of individuals, using the faces of a few to represent the travails  many. Given the sheer scale of the destruction, itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a reductive but effective tactic, especially in terms of providing an overall snapshot of municipal recovery. We meet a police officer, Matt Gates, who breaks down while recalling a womanï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s narrow escape during the blaze, and whose work ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ dramatically redefined in the wake of the tragedy ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ takes its toll on his family life. We also meet former Paradise mayor Steve ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Woodyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Culleton, who was once the self-described ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½town drunkï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ before he sobered up and became an elected official, a turnaround narrative that gently underscores the townï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s own hopes of regeneration.
The most engaging figure is school superintendent Michelle John, who determinedly goes about the daunting task of providing for the young students of Paradise, many of whom are now homeless. A scene of John comforting students in makeshift classrooms hits especially close to home; as an image of American schools being uprooted, nt, farther-reaching crisis of the COVID-19 pandemic.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Rebuilding Paradiseï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ was finished and first shown atthis yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Sundance Film Festivalwell before the pandemic erupted, and as a result it doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t address the myriad ways in which the coronavirus hashindered and even reversed Paradiseï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s recovery. (A sequel or two may be in order.) As the film makes clear, the town was facing enough obstacles already, from the gutting of infrastructure to the toxic chemicals that were released during the fire, poisoning the water supply. And thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not even mentioning the enormous financial burdens and the incalculable trauma suffered by those who lost loved ones, homes, memories and an entire way of life.
Howard has made documentaries before (among them last yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Pavarottiï¿½ï¿½ï¿½), and he also notably played with fire in the 1991 dramaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Backdraft.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½His work here is solid, sensitive and unobtrusive. He and his collaborators (they include cinestirring drama in quotidian moments, from a bittersweet Christmas celebration to the many tense meetings where the people of Paradise try to figure out a way forward. A lot of those meetings, one of which is attended by Erin Brockovich, are focused on legal action againstPacific Gas & Electricfor the role its equipment played in starting the blaze. (Earlier this year, PG&E pleaded guilty to84 counts of involuntary manslaughterin the Camp fire.)
But the documentary also points to sustained drought, rising temperatures and other environmental conditions that essentially cleared a path for fires to wipe out Paradise, as well as other communities in the future. Howard sounds a queasy note of alarm, placing the Camp fire in the context of the recent Australian bushfires, the floods that have decimated South Asia and other deadly disasters exacerbated by climate change. When a Paradise resident gives a speech at filmï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s end and declares, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We arenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t alone in this,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ her ostensibly reass but sound like a warning.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Rebuilding Paradiseï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Rating:PG-13, for intense scenes of peril, thematic elements and some strong language
Running time:1 hour, 30 minutes

column1: Second effort to boost wildfire funding falls flat in the California Legislature
column6:
SACRAMENTOï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½An eleventh-hour push in the California Legislature to direct$500 million to wildfire response and preventionfell flat Monday, marking the second late attempt to boost fire funding that failed in the last week.
The efforts to secure more money for wildfires fizzled out as blazes burned more than a million acres across the state during the frenetic final days of the legislative year.
Arguing that California needs to do more to prevent fires, Democrats in the Senate came up with the plan to spend $500 million dollars on fires aftera bill to generate $3 billion for wildfire and climate projectsthrough the extension of a fee on electricity bills failed to gain traction last week.
But even the scaled-back spending plan was fraught with legislative hurdles that proved too difficult to overcome and the plan was scuttled before it was officially introduced. Senate President Pro Tem Toni Atkinsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ office confirmed that the proposal was dead late Monday.
The late nature of the proposal wod Gov. Gavin Newsom to submit a statement to the Legislature saying the bill was necessary to address a state of emergency and waive a state law that prevents lawmakers from amending legislation in the final hours before the Legislature adjourns for the year.
Action from Newsom also hinged on the ability of the Senate and Assembly to strike a deal to support the plan, which never materialized.
The push came after lawmakers introduced AB 1659 one week ago to add 10 years to an existing utility fee for bonds to pay for wildfire and climate projects.
AB 1659 repeated a financial model lawmakers had created last year when they extended the fee for 15 years to 2035 to generate bonds used to pay for wildfire damages caused by utility equipment. The 2019 law made it easier for utilities to avoid being on the hook for wildfire damages through a new safety certification process and created a $21-billion fund as an additional shield against losses from blazes linked to their equipment.
The attempt to tap customers for another decade of fees didnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t sit well with ratepayers, lawmakers and some of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s most powerful business groups. The California Chamber of Commerce, the California Farm Bureau Federation, the Western States Petroleum Assn., Pacific Gas & Electric, San Diego Gas & Electric and the Utility Reform Network were among the opponents of the bill.
By Saturday, lawmakers had dropped the extension on ratepayers and instead mapped out a plan to come up with $500 million from Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s cap-and-trade program ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ which requires companies to buy permits to release greenhouse gas emissions ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ as well as state general fund revenues and a 2018 bond measure.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Our state is on fire,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Sen. Ben Allen (D-Santa Monica) as he and other lawmakers attempted to earn support for the proposal. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This is a vital and urgent need and I certainly hope we can get it done.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The money would have gone to a variety of efforts aimed at addressing wildfires and climatr, emergency shelters, warning and detection systems,hardening projects, forest health and workforce training.

column1: California could soon end its dumb policy on inmate firefighters. What took so long?
column6:
All it would take is one phone call from a fire department. Any fire department.
Joshua McKinney assured me of this one recent morning, standing in the shade in his grandmotherï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s driveway in South Los Angeles as an LAPD helicopter circled overhead.
For weeks now, ever since the 26-year-old got out of prison in June, he has been trying to earn a paycheck in an economy thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s in shambles and dreaming of returning to the fire lines, where he worked to get months off his sentence, earning a pittance.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I went in mainly to get out early, but as I was there, I actually fell in love with it,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ McKinney explained. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I was like, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Dang, I never knew how much I loved hard work.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
He and thousands of other Californians are barred from suiting up again because of their criminal records, and that is just stupid for a state that is woefully short on resources to fight fires. In recent weeks,firefighters have been overrunin Northern California, slammed from all sidd scorched whatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s already topped 1.4 million acres.
Thankfully, this could soon change.
After years of pushing, mostly by Assemblywoman Eloise Gomez Reyes (D-Grand Terrace), the Legislature on Sunday night sent a bill to the governorï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s desk that would help former prisoners ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ most of them Black and Latino ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ to earn the emergency medical technician license necessary to become full-time, year-round firefighters with the state, and numerous counties and cities.
Under AB 2147, former prisoners who have successfully worked in one of theCalifornia Department of Corrections and Rehabilitationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s fire campswill be able to petition a judge to quickly expunge their records and waive parole time. They then would be able to apply not only for an EMT license but a host of other licenses required by other professions.
Logical, right?
All it took was a bit of creative policymaking to please the firefightersï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ union, a pandemic that has emptied prisons and fire camps alike, an earestroyed scores of homes in Northern California, an eye-popping unemployment rate, and nonstop protests over the long-standing racial inequities of the criminal justice system.
That said, it shouldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have taken all of these compounding catastrophes to summon the political will to rightone of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s most notorious wrongs.
We use thousands of prisoners to do the grunt work of fighting fires, pay them a slave wage to do it and then, when they get out, we refuse to offer them a job doing the same thing for an actual living wage with benefits. And then we have the nerve to crow about our progressive values on criminal justice reform. Meanwhile, the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s recidivism rate remains ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½stubbornly high,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ averaging 50% in the last decade,according to a recent state audit.
Even the Los Angeles Lakers took California to task over this hypocrisy last week, issuing a rare tweet in support of then-pending legislation from Reyes.
Thank you to all of our firefighters and first respated men and women fighting the current California wildfires.Human rights are everyoneï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s rights.Create a pathway for former inmates who successfully completed fire camp while incarcerated.pic.twitter.com/U0j6TsfKBL
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We know that these incarcerated firefighters have already demonstrated a commitment and desire to turn their life around,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Reyes said, noting that corrections officials preemptively weed out prisoners who have committed serious offenses, such as rape, or have a history of escape with violence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I would hope that most of us would agree that an individual willing to face down a fire and smoke is much more than the sum of their previous mistakes.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t want a sentence that has been completed to become a life sentence. And unfortunately, our criminal justice system has done just that. Even after somebody has completed their sentence, theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re living a life sentence, because so many doors are shut to them.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This is something McKinney is t of prison and on parole, he has applied for one of the few spots in the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protectionï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Firefighter Training and Certification Program, run out of the Ventura Conservation Camp. Launched a couple of years ago, it helps people with criminal records compete for entry-level firefighting jobs with state, federal and local agencies.
California
For well over a week, hundreds of inmates have chain-sawed through relentless thickets of chaparral, cutting lines through the backcountry to thwart the fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s sudden rushes at homes.
In the meantime, though, McKinney is at a bit of a loss about what to do with himself.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m just, I donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t know,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said with a shrug. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Well, Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m not gonna say I donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t know. I know what I want to do. But I donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have the proper certifications.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
McKinneyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s friend, Eric Hunt, went through a similar experience when he was released from prison after a stint in a o find out that he couldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t, he said. Then he landed a job doing recruitment for a jobs program for at-risk youth and veterans. Then one of his bosses found out he was on parole and Hunt, who grew up in Pomona and now lives in Altadena, said he was let go.
So now Hunt has joined the ranks of Californians looking for steady employment in an economy turned upside down by the COVID-19 pandemic. Nearly4.8 million people in the state are collecting unemployment benefits. The most recent figures, according to the U.S. Labor Department, showed 209,500 initial claims during the week ending Aug. 22 ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a number that is going up, not down.
To make ends meet now, Hunt does a little of this and a little of that, he said. A natural salesman with a quick wit and a tendency to talk in inspirational koans ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Like my uncle told me, you ainï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t had a best friend ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½til you been oneï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he sells fruit cobblers at farmers markets and wants to teach paint-and-sip classes on he loves to do is talk about wildfires and about fighting them, usually with full-on reenactments and sound effects.
Like the time Hunt was ordered to help set a controlled burn. It was the first real wildfire he had experienced.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I didnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t know fire grew so fast and could get so hot. And Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m like, man, back of my neck is hot. And I look and thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s just this wall of fire there ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ 200 feet in the air, just fire. All of this air starts to whip these trees around and Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m like, oh my God.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
He just started running.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m swinging my arms, and Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m flinging fuel all behind me on the bushes. I finally burst through the other side. And thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s everybody, and they all start falling out laughing because I look panicked. My hard hat is on sideways, my goggles are down around my neck.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Or the time during the Woolsey fire that he had to help a member of the crew down Boney Mountain in Malibu.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s tired, his legsy backpack, and I slowly start to descend.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
McKinney has plenty of stories, too. Like the time he and his crew had been working for hours in the heat, hacking away at brush and trees with packs of heavy gear on their backs, when another wind-whipped blaze suddenly erupted in the distance.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m just standing and Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m looking at it. You can kind of see the smoke start to rise and rise. I felt the wind start to pick up because,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said pausing for emphasis, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve got to be aware of the wind directions on you at any moment.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Soon, McKinney said he was bent over once again, clearing brush with a chain saw ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ only this time, in the face of 30-foot flames.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I never sweated that much in my life,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.
Both McKinney and Hunt credit their time in fire camp with teaching them to be better human beings. They speak with pride ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and a bit of surprise ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ about the residents who have offered thanks and food and water f respective fire crews.
For Hunt, in particular, who has been in and out of police custody for a variety of crimes since he was a teenager, the fire camp experience was life changing. He said he became a person whom his mother could once again be proud of.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You become an entirely different person from who you were,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½So itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s difficult. Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½d love it if they just said, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Hey, come on down and report.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
All it would take is one phone call ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and the promise of a salary that actually befits a firefighter. Not even the risk of contracting COVID-19 is a deterrent.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Just give us two radios,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ McKinney said, as Hunt nodded. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll make it happen.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

President Trumpand his allies are trying to depict protests over racial injustice as a law-and-order campaign issue, attacking Democratic leaders, refusing to condemn deadly vigilante violence and touting a purportedly tranquil ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Donald Trumpï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s America.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Former Vice PresidentJoe Bidenhas accused Trump of inciting violence for political gain.

Against the backdrop of a still-raging coronavirus outbreak, the White House has offered the clearest signal yet of a calculatedGOP strategy of exploiting voter fears of violenceas the campaign against Biden enters the final stretch and Trump trails in the polls.
The strategy closely resembles the one Trumpssfully, in the 2018 midterm election, when he spent weeks warning of ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½caravansï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ of migrants trying to reach the U.S. border with Mexico. This time, the effort is aimed at portraying urban Democratic strongholds as threatening and lawless.

Starting today, California is implementinga new system designed to rekindle the economy, which has been decimated by the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: In this yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s atypical California fire season, politicians find the blame game wonï¿½
column6:
SACRAMENTOï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This wildfire season is different. And it must be frustrating for many politicians. It certainly is for pundits. Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s because there is no one really to blame.
A cardinal rule of politics and punditry is to clearly state the problem, point out whoï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s at fault and say what should be done about it.
But during the current wildfires, no human apparently is at fault. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Mother Natureï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s handiwork ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ mostly her lightning strikes. No mortal can turn those  fire bolts off.
OK, we could prepare better for them and should.
But so far, it doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t seem to be Pacific Gas & Electric Co.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s fault. Unlike in past fire seasons, the utilityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s old power equipment isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t tumbling down and igniting flammable brush or dead trees it should have cleared.
There havenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t been any nutty arsonists out there that we know about. Nor careless campers who left their breakfast fires smoldering. No smokers tossing lit cigarette butts from the and public officials also cite global warming, including Gov. Gavin Newsom. They may be right. But lightning was around long before we started burning fossil fuel.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m not in denial about climate change,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Newsom told reporters last week. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½If you donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t believe in climate change, come to the state of California and we will educate youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Not just wildfires ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ droughts and floods. Snowpack [diminishing] and the like. I could go on.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Newsomï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s predecessor, four-term Gov. Jerry Brown, was a fatalist about wildfires.
California
The California Legislature abandoned a bill to extend a fee on utility customers to generate $500 million for wildfire projects.
While inspecting devastation from Butte Countyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s cataclysmic Camp fire in 2018, Brown was asked by a reporter, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½How do we curb these fires?ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You know,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Brown answered, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve had fires for long before the Europeans showed up here.er more than 300,000 [people in California]. Now we have 40 million and we have a totally different situation.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½So itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not one thing. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s people. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s how people live, itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s where they live and itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the changing climateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½. And the truth is ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re going to have more difficulties,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Things are not going to get better. Theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re going to get more challenging because of the continuing alternation in the climate ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ lack of moisture, early snowmelt and faster winds, the whole thing.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unquestionably we need to slow global warming. But to do that we need a U.S. president who doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t think climate change is a socialist hoax.
Whatever we Californians and all Americans do to wean ourselves off fossil fuel, however, it isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t going to stop wildfires for the foreseeable future.
Stephen J. Pyne, a professor emeritus at Arizona State University who specializes in environmental history, put itanaged to live with fire. We need to relearn how to coexist with it because it isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t going away ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ it canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t. Unlike for COVID-19, no fire vaccine is possible.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½At this point in our fire-powered warming world, even as we ratchet down fossil fuel burning, landscape fires will likely ratchet upï¿½ï¿½ï¿½. We can ready ourselves to truly manage fire or scramble in blustering incredulity,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he wrote. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½But the fires are coming.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The August lightning strikes, however, were freakish and relatively rare.
Lightning like that doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t happen every season. In one three-day span, there were 12,000 lightning strikes in California ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ an average of 167 an hour.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s an unusual amount of lightning,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ says Nick Schuler, deputy chief at the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.
Climate & Environment
As Southern Californians increasingly flock to the mountains for relief from a recent heat wave and months-long coronavirusites.
Other big lightning bursts came in 2008 and 1987, Schuler says. But this yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s was bigger than both of those. And this summer, the vegetation is especially flammable because of an abnormally dry winter.
President Trump habitually accuses California Democrats offailing to clear the forestsof dead trees and brush that fuel fires. Newsom ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½has done a terrible job of forest management,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the Republican president claims.
Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s typical Trump. The federal government owns and manages 57% of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s 33 million acres of forests. The state owns only 2.2% and local governments less than 1%. Private landowners have about 40%. The feds should clean up their own mess.
No argument, California governments and private landowners all have been irresponsibly tardy in clearing out fire-fueling brush and dead timber. The state government has been trying to catch up during the last three years. It has cleaned up 90,000 acres. Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a good start, but itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s just a smýs out there ready to burn.
Forest cleaning should be a top state priority and it apparently is. There are plans to annually reduce fire fuel on 1 million acres in partnership with the federal government.
Newsom, Brown and legislators deserve credit for recently hopping to it on firefighting and prevention.
Theyýýýve purchased 12 twin-engine Black Hawk helicopters retrofitted for firefighting, replacing old Vietnam War-era single-engine Huey birds. The Black Hawks fly faster and can dump more water.
Cal Fire has added 13 new fire engines and 858 more firefighters ýýý plus a lot of new technology such as wildfire alert cameras.
Since Newsom took office, the state has spent about $500 million beefing up Cal Fire.
As of Friday, 14,600 firefighters ýýý state, local and federal ýýý using 2,400 fire engines and more than 100 aircraft were battling more than two dozen major blazes.
The stateýýýs long-term solution: Keep doing what itýýýs doing ýýý only much more of it.

column1: California Democrats scuttle wildfire utility fee plan, turn to Newsom in last-ditch effort
column6:
SACRAMENTOï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Facing heavy opposition, California lawmakers have scrapped a last-minute bill toextend fees for utility customersand plan to replace it with a more modest call for $500 million in emergency fire response and mitigation efforts.
The new proposal requires Gov. Gavin Newsom to waive a state law that prevents legislators from amending bills in the final hours before the Legislature adjourns for the year.
The decision to abandon Assembly Bill 1659 came just five days after lawmakers introduced the measure. The legislationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s reliance on a 10-year extension of fees on utility bills ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ at a cost of more than $3 billion to customers ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ to pay for wildfire mitigation and climate projects drew sharp criticism from ratepayer advocates and utilities.
The new plan, pushed by Democrats in the state Senate, would instead tap into proceeds from Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s cap-and-trade program ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ which requires companies to buy permits to release  greenhouse gas emissions ï¿½ï¿½ a 2018 bond measure. The money would be spent on a variety of efforts aimed at addressing wildfires and climate change, including cooling centers, back-up solar power, emergency shelters, warning and detection systems,hardening projects, forest health and workforce training.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve had 1.7 million acres that have already burned this year and we havenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t even gotten to the peak of wildfire season,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said state Sen. Ben Allen (D-Santa Monica), who is among the Democrats pushing the proposal. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Either weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re going to continue spending money to fight the fires and help communities rebuild and address the devastation after the fact, or we can try to act now to be more proactive.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
But Allen and other proponents would have to overcome major hurdles to pass the proposal with less than two days left in the legislative year.
Proposition 54, a 2016 voter-approved amendment to the California Constitution, requires a bill to be in print for 72 hours before the Legislatudjourn for the year Monday night, the new proposal would require  Newsom to submit a statement to the Legislature saying itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s necessary to address a state of emergency.
If Newsom takes action, legislators plan to make the bill a majority-vote proposal tied to the state budget, an easier threshold to clear than the two-thirds vote that would have been required to pass AB 1659.
Newsom probably wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t intervene unless the Senate and Assembly reach an agreement to support the new proposal.
Senate President Pro Tem Toni Atkins (D-San Diego) said she was prepared to negotiate.
Atkins ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½is not taking a position on any specific proposal, but is willing and ready to engage to get something done in the next 36 hours,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ her office said in a statement.
But Assembly Speaker Anthony Rendon (D-Lakewood) questioned whether the bill was necessary to address the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wildfire emergency.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Given the governorï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s office has not yet engaged with us on this proposal, I donï¿½ï¿½e 72-hour rule,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Rendon said in a statement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This rule is designed to provide transparency, and overturning it should be done sparingly. Wildfire prevention and climate change are important issues in California, and deserve thoughtful discussion to figure out potential funding proposals.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Assemblyman Chris Holden (D-Pasadena), the chair of the Assembly utilities and energy committee, strongly objected to the use of ratepayer-raised  funds for AB 1659. Through a staff member, Holden declined to comment on the replacement proposal because he said he had not been able to review the billï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s language.
Other key members of the Assembly, including Richard Bloom (D-Santa Monica), who introduced AB 1659, and Jim Wood (D-Healdsburg), did not immediately respond to  requests for comment.
A spokesman for Newsom declined to comment on the new proposal and whether he would waive the 72-hour rule.
The decision to pare back the original spending plan under AB 1659 comes after the bill faced fiesses and ratepayer advocates.
A coalition of business groups ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ including the California Chamber of Commerce, the California Farm Bureau Federation, the Western States Petroleum Assn. and other influential groups ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ sent a letter to the Senate last week opposing the bill for requiring customers of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s three largest investor-owned utilities to pay for projects unrelated to their electrical service.
The business groups wrote that ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½choosing to fund bits and pieces of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s overall wildfire response and non-utility programs and projects solely on the backs of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ratepayers at a time when businesses are closing, unemployment is skyrocketing, and our economy is faltering is not an appropriate solution.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
AB 1659 would have added 10 years to an existing utility fee, already extended last year by lawmakers to 2035 to pay for wildfire damages caused by utility equipment. The extension would have cost ratepayers 96 cents a month, or more thanto pay for wildfire prevention work.
Newsom and the Legislature approved AB 1054 to establish the wildfire fund last summer amid pressure from Wall Street to reduce the utility industryï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s liability for  damage linked to their electrical poles and equipment. The law made it easier for utilities to avoid being on the hook for wildfire damages through a new safety certification process and created a $21-billion fund as an additional shield against losses from blazes linked to their equipment.
Pacific Gas & Electric and San Diego Gas & Electric have opposed this yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s proposal, AB 1659, saying their customers shouldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½shoulder the financial burden for activities and public projects that benefit the entire state.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½AB 1659 would impose extra costs on IOU [investor-owned utility] customers, which would be viewed negatively by lenders, ratings agencies, and capital markets, further exacerbating the already challenged credit ratings of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s IOUs,ï¿½ï¿½ýýAB 1659 therefore threatens to undermine the collaborative progress made to restore the financial health of the stateýýýs IOUs, while imposing an additional, unnecessary burden on IOU customers.ýýý
The utilities are expected to remain neutral on the replacement proposal because it does not require an extension of the ratepayer fee.
Mark Toney, executive director of the Utility Reform Network, ripped AB 1659 in a legislative hearing last week, saying the bill broke a promise the state made last year when it said ratepayer costs for wildfires would be capped at $10.5 billion ýýý the cost of the 15-year fee increase for the wildfire fund.
ýýýAB 1659 is nothing short of a last-minute backroom deal to loot ratepayers,ýýý Toney said.

column1: Illegal campfires spark fear of wildfire in California forests
column6:
Big Bear Lake, Calif.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½As darkness fell on a campsite in a well-hidden glen in the San Bernardino Mountains recently, the soft clatter of a laptop keyboard on a portable picnic table was joined by the sound of footsteps trampling undergrowth as two U.S. Forest Rangers strode forward and said, in turn, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Howdy.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The rangers methodically scanned the tiny, lonely patch of Holcomb Valley wilderness in which Jonathan Hong, 31, of Beverly Hills, was composing the opening chapters of his first science fiction novel. It didnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t take long for the rangers to find what they were looking for.
Nodding toward a nearby mound of charred wood encircled by softball-sized rocks, Ranger Chon Bribiescas asked, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Is that a campfire over there?ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Yeah. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s just a small one,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Hong, replied nervously, adding, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not mine.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Instantly and quietly, Bribiescas and Zachary Behrens set to work. With their bare hands, they gauged the heat otossing them into the forest.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t allow campfire rings like this to become reusable,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Behrens said, spreading dirt over the ashes with his boots.
Moments later, they were back in their pickups and trundling down a one-lane dirt road cutting through Holcomb Valley, about five miles north of Big Bear Lake, on a night patrol to eliminate illegal campfires.
As Southern Californians increasingly flock to the mountains for relief from a recent heat wave and months-long coronavirus restrictions, hundreds of illegal campfires have sprung up in dispersed campsites. Unlike developed campsites, which offer groomed campgrounds, toilet facilities and often fire rings or grills, dispersed campsites are simply forested areas where visitors pitch a tent.
So far this year, forest officials have documented a 270% increase in illegal campfires in the San Bernardino National Forest, the most densely populated and heavily used national forest in the United States. Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s  a rise from 189 betwn 2019 to about 700 during the same period in 2020.
Under current fire restrictions, building a campfire is allowed only in fire rings provided by the Forest Service in some developed recreation sites. The same goes for wood or charcoal barbecues.
But the problem persists amid afire seasonlike no other. As the pine air filled with the snarling sounds of vehicles clawing for traction along the badly rutted dirt roads leading into Holcomb Valley, Northern California was under a state of emergency as firefighters battled more than 560 lightning-stoked wildfires across the state that have claimed the lives of at least seven people, destroyed hundreds of homes and scorched more than 1 million acres.
California
A small Cessna soared high above the Mojave Desert recently, its engine growling in the choppy morning air.
The tensions play out every day as thousands of vacationers stream into this popular resort community looking forward to an alpine escape of crisp mountain air, cool forest trails and cozy campfires.
Instead, they are greeted by a grim reality: By 1 p.m. on a recent Friday, all 13 campgrounds in the San Bernardino range were filled, and traffic along the main route into the community was clogged due to an onslaught of SUVs and four-wheel drive vehicles loaded with coolers, bicycles, fishing and climbing gear and barbecues.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½These visitors have two choices,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Behrens, 39, said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½They can turn around and head home, or search for a suitable place to camp for free in, say, Holcomb Valley.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Many tourists think the effort is worth it. They have driven more than a hundred miles in their own vehicles to get to Big Bear Lake, a city of 6,000 year-round residents and summer crowds of more than 100,000 on Labor Day weekend. Today is their day.
But because of the increasing tourist pressure, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½weekdays are now like weekends and weekends are like major holidays,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Behrens said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½And with the surge of visitors has come an uptick in illegal campfires all over the forese issue across the state, as increasing numbers of summer travelers are avoiding planes and cruise ships and placing more value on forest recreation near their homes, blurring the distinctions between urban life and deep woods.
On a recent Friday in the San Bernardino forest, rangers discovered 11 illegal fire rings. In most cases, nearby campers insisted they had no idea who built them. In any case, Bribiescas left a written warning that said, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Friendly reminder: No campfires or charcoal bbq. Thank you.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
At sunrise the following morning, they smothered a few dozen more.
Then there was Andrew Dewlaney, 28, a middle school physical education teacher struggling with online teaching, and his wife Coree, 29, a nurse at the John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital emergency room, who worried that their hard-won weekend getaway in Holcomb Valley was about to come to an abrupt end when the rangers walked up and said, in turn, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Hello there.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
It was 109 degrees in the shade with high humidity e in Indio, Calif., that morning, they said. The traffic congestion they encountered in Big Bear Lake that afternoon was a crushing disappointment. After several hours of searching unsuccessfully for an available space at a forest service campground, they ventured into Holcomb Valley.
The good news: They had a permit to use a propane-powered fire pit filled with lava rocks that they brought to provide a smoke-free semblance of a wood-fueled campfire. The bad news: the device was sitting on a thick bed of highly flammable pine needles.
But the rangers were sympathetic. Bribiescas used a rake to remove the needles from a patch of soil roughly five feet in diameter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You should be good to go now,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.
Overall, the rangers encountered little resistance during their campfire patrol under a big sky filled with owls and a dazzle of stars. Whether they prevented a potentially catastrophic wildfire was anyoneï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s guess.
For Behrens, Bribiescas and Smith, it was all part of a dayï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s woaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s urban national forest.

column1: Why Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s 2020 lightning fires got so big s
column6:
When state fire authorities announced recently that the CZU Lightning Complex fire had quadrupled in size in just one day, an audible gasp rose from the audience.
Although lightning fires have been scorching the state since prehistoric times, the speed with which the SCU and LNU lightning complex fires became the second- and third-largest blazes ever recorded in California has startled emergency officials and strained firefighting resources. The fires have killed seven people, destroyed more than 2,100 buildings and made air unhealthy across the Bay Area.
And things may only get worse in the future, experts say.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a direct relationship between heat and fire, and increasing heat is inevitable for at least a few decades,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Michael Gerrard, director of Columbia Universityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Sabin Center for Climate Change Law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½If you like 2020, youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re going to love 2050.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
So why have this yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s fires burned more than 1.4 million acres of the stateï¿½ï¿½ne country? After all, the Lightning Siege of 2008, when nearly 800,000 acres burned, was the first time the National Guard had been called in to help in 40 years as resources were stretched to the limit.
The answer is complicated.
The destiny of all wildfires is shaped by the fire behavior triangle ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ fuel, weather and topography ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ according to Craig Clements, a professor at San Jose Stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Fire Weather Research Laboratory.
But there were additional factors involved in this most recent outbreak. A summer heat wave magnified by climate change combined with tropical moisture and storm energy to create thunderstorms. The resulting lightning strikes pelted a region with a history of difficult firefighting and another area thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s seen numerous fires in the recent past.
The state- and locally-maintained coastal mountains in Central California, where the CZU  Lightning Complex is burning, have a history of challenging firefighters. In 2016, in Monterey County north of the current firlping contain the stubbornSoberanes fire, which burned 50 homes while flames lived for months in the rangeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s steep canyons and impassable terrain.
In 2003, south of Livermore, where a part of the SCU Lightning Complex is now burning, 53 firefighters were overrun in the middle of the night and used their shelters in what may have been the second-largest shelter deployment by crews in U.S. history, Clements said.
In both instances, just as is happening now,  temperatures did not drop significantly overnight nor was any ocean moisture reintroduced into the landscapeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s higher elevations. In the summer, a high-pressure system settles over the Pacific and rotates, steering warm, dry air over the coastal rangeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s upper elevations while squeezing cool, moist air into the marine layer below, said San Jose State atmospheric scientist Alison Bridger.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s basically why we donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t get rain in the summer,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said.
Throw in an extreme heat wave, and fire risk rises simely large, fast destructive fires without any offshore winds is very unusual,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said UCLA climate scientist Daniel Swain. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½All of this hints at something which we know to be true ... the state of the vegetation, the state of the fuels was pretty extraordinary.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In fact, most of the areas burning in the three lightning complex fires are considered to be in moderate to severe drought, according to the most recent U.S. Drought Monitor reportreleased Thursday.Huge chunks of each fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s footprint include areas that havenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t seen fires in decades and were jackpots of dead and dry tinder.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Unfortunately, as the climate continues to warm, the table is being set for these extreme fires more often,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Swain said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It means the ceiling on how bad these fires can be is continuing to increase.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The night that the hundreds-of-miles-wide lightning storm set all these fires in motion, a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½heat burstï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ before sunrise hit parts of wine country, e from 80 to 100 degrees in under two hours. While experts say it  probably didnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have a direct impact on the fires, it certainly didnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t help matters and foreshadowed the challenging conditions to come.
From Tuesday to Wednesday, winds flowed downslope into the Sacramento Valley from the mountains between Oregon and California, shedding moisture along the way. When they hit the wine country hills, they were bone dry and influenced the fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s explosive growth, said National Weather Service meteorologist Cory Miller. The LNU Lightning Complex fire grew tenfold in 36 hours, from 12,200 acres the morning of Aug. 18 to 124,000 acres the following night, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.
Sarah Johnson and the Emerald Hills Horse Ranch, in Winters, were in the fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s path.
Johnson, 29, is originally from Ohio and knows thunderstorms, so two weeks ago she kicked back in a hammock to enjoy a flavor of the Midwest as lightning flashed across the horsa and  Mt. Vaca.
But soon, the storms were replaced with smoke, and then falling ash. Johnson and her boyfriend were glued to their phones, listening to scanner traffic from first responders about the fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s movements. The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection website was working only intermittently, overwhelmed by a surge in web traffic from around the globe.
As the fire made its late-night surge Aug. 18 and 19, Johnsonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s boyfriendï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s phone began ringing incessantly, the ranchï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s boarders trying to reach him to warn him of the incoming fire.
The couple woke up and sprung into action, waking neighbors, loading up horses as trailers arrived and helping to knock down small spot fires that dotted the ranch pasture. The ranch lost power sometime during the scramble.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It was incredibly windy and smoky and you could see a fire tornado forming, and the rate of spread was incredible,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Johnson said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The fire was just so bright, thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s how  several hours, their neighborsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ homes burned. The fire was fast and the countyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s emergency alert system didnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t reach many of them until it was too late, if at all, Johnson said.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I remember at one point I just stopped and looked and said, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Where are all the fire trucks?ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and it was just another surreal moment and I realized that nobody was coming,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said.
Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a concern that as these fires hit the same areas again and again, theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll permanently change California, and not for the better.
A moderate fire can clear out underbrush and competing trees, giving a healthy forest room to breathe. But if it visits again and again ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ as has happened  in parts of Napa County in recent years ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ those native grasses and plants give up the fight and invasive plants move in, similar towhatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s happened in Southern California.Oftentimes those new species can spread fire faster.
California has choices to make since fire is inevit climate law director. Building codes can be updated. Utility infrastructure can be modernized and better regulated. Decisions on where homes are built and how forests are managed can be made with fire risk and native ecology in mind.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s very much like managed retreat on the coastline,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Gerrard said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The hope is that recurrent, related disasters will be a wake-up call.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
