The benefits of indirect work can take a while to show, said Jim Mackensen, a public information officer for the Windy fire, who said intense fire behavior and rough terrain have often made direct firefighting techniques infeasible.
An infestation ofbark beetlesa few years ago killed a large number of drought-weakened trees, felling them and strewing their parched carcasses on the ground.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½When the fire gets into those areas, it sets all those logs and stuff on fire, so itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s got a tremendous amount of energy,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Mackensen said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t put firefighters right on the line to fight those fires.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In many instances, crews instead have backed away from the edge of the fire and put containment lines off roadways or dozer lines while waiting ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½for the said he expected containment on the fires to increase over the next several days as the flames reach those lines.
Roughly 158 homes in the Sequoia National Park, in the Lodgepole area, and nearby communities of Three Rivers and Hartland are threatened by the KNP Complex. Personnel were prioritizing protecting those structures Tuesday, officials said.
Meanwhile, crews from Tulare County were assessing potential damage to homes and other properties in the Sugarloaf and Pine Flat areas, along the south end of the Windy fire, where flames swept through in recent days.
Climate & Environment
In California and beyond, some people are deeply in grief, stunned that flames could again imperil some of Earthï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s oldest living things.
Despite fire officialsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ cautious optimism that indirect firefighting methods will pay off, albeit more slowly, thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s general consensus that both the KNP Complex and Windy fires will continue to swell.
Years of drought have primed the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s vegetation toburnproblem firefighters are contending with up and down the state.
A winter and spring oflittle rainand minimal snow runoff ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ followed by months of unusually warm conditions and severalsummer heat wavesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ left wildlands primed to burn fast, giving fire crews little time to get a handle on flames before they explode.
And adding to fire expertsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ concerns is the fact that much of the dry vegetation this year hasnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t yet encountered severe winds, which tend to arrive in the form ofSanta Anasand sundowners later in the year.
When the extreme dryness does meet strong winds it can quickly spell disaster.

column1: Fawn fire arson suspect said she was boiling creek water to remove bear urine
column6:
A Palo Alto woman facing felony charges of arson in connection with a wildfire burning in Shasta County told authorities she was trying to boil bear urine out of creek water the day the fire started, according to a criminal complaint.
Alexandra Souverneva, 30, is accused of ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½willfully, unlawfully, and maliciouslyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ setting fire to forest land in the Mountain Gate area near Redding on Wednesday,  igniting the Fawn fire, which  hasdestroyed 185 structuresand forced the evacuation of thousands of residents.
She faces afelony arson chargewith an enhanced charge of committing arson during a state of emergency. Together, the charges could result in up to nine years in prison, Shasta County Dist. Atty. Stephanie Bridgett said. She has pleaded not guilty.
Souverneva told Cal Fire officials that she was hiking to Canada when she became thirsty and found a puddle of water near a dry creek bed, according to court records. The water contained bear urine, Souverneva said, and after an unsuccessful attempt twith a tea bag, she tried to start a fire to boil the water instead. But, she said, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½it was too wet for the fire to start.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
She drank the water anyway and continued to walk uphill, she told authorities, until she saw smoke and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½airplanes dropping pink stuffï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and then contacted the fire department.
Quarry workers reported seeing a woman matching Souvernevaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s description who was ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½acting irrationallyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ near where the fire began Wednesday afternoon. Court documents indicate the woman continued walking east into the vegetation, leaving behind two carbon dioxide cartridges and a battery along a dirt road.
Later that night, fire officials found Souverneva as theybattled the growing blazeand assessed her for possible dehydration. At the time, she was carrying a functioning cigarette lighter and a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½pink and white item containing a green leafy substance she admitted to smoking that day,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Cal Fire Officer Matt Alexander reported.
She also was carryind near the quarry, according to the criminal complaint.
California
Alexandra Souverneva, 30, of Palo Alto, was charged with arson in connection with the 8,500-acre fire.
In addition to arson charges, Souverneva, who was appointed a public defender, could face additional charges as the Fawn fire continues to burn. She remains in custody in lieu of $150,000 bail.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We are still waiting to get the final damage assessment to know what the extent of structural damage ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ before we can decide whether we can file additional charges,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Bridgett said Tuesday. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I will say that additional charges are probably likely based on what I know so far.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Fire officials think Souverneva may also be responsible for a vegetation fire in Shasta Lake City that ignited the previous evening. And Bridgett said she may be linked to other fires in both the county and elsewhere in California.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It is my experience that arsonists are responsible for multiple fires and will light multiple fires in a in the complaint.
Arson arrests have not been uncommon in California this year. Cal Fire Battalion Chief J.T. Zulliger said  the Shasta-Trinity unit of Cal Fire has made 14 arson arrests this year, and there have been 103 such arrests statewide.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We are still in critical fire danger and ... we ask the public to be extremely careful and cautious having to do with any kind of outside activity that may spark a fire,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We still have a long way to go until the rains come.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Fawn fire has nowburned more than 8,570 acres, leading Gov. Gavin Newsom on Monday to declare a state of emergency in Shasta County.
The blaze grew steadily for several days, but by Sunday night, officials said itsforward progress had been stopped. On Tuesday morning, it was 65% contained, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.
Despite the containment, mandatory evacuation orders remain in place, and fire crews were preparing for potential heavy winds that could carryfires.

column1: How to watch Jaime Lowe discuss ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Breathing Fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ at the L.A. Tim
column6:
California has always had a fire problem; now that problem is a constant crisis.
Among Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s solutions is a nearly invisible workforce of inmate firefighters. Depending on the year, inmates make up as much as 30% of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wildland fire crews, saysauthor Jaime Lowe.
In her new book, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Breathing Fire,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Lowe takes readers to the front lines of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wildfires through the experiences of the women inmates who volunteer for intense fire training and risk their lives to save a state in peril.
Lowe joined the L.A. Times Book Club Sept. 28 for a conversation with Times columnist Erika D. Smith. You can watch the  live-streaming event onYouTube,TwitterandFacebook.
Lowe says the book was inspired by a2016 Times articleabout Shawna Lynn Jones, a 22-year-old inmate who was struck in the head by a falling boulder while working the fire lines in Malibu. Jones, serving a three-year sentence for violating probation after a drug offense, died just six weeks before herve years, Lowe set out to document the lives of the women of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Conservation Camp program: their stories, their training and the inequities of a system that paid Shawna Jones just$2.56 a day or $1 an hourfor working the fire lines.

column1: On the climate crisis, delay has become the new form of denial
column6:
Whether itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the apocalyptic wildfires that once againravaged Californiaand the West this summer, aheat domeover the Pacific Northwest that made parts of Canada feel like Phoenix on the Fourthof July or thedevastating floodsin my state of Pennsylvania after Hurricane Ida dumped monthsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ worth of rainfall in a few hours, it is clear that dangerous climate change is upon us.
One can no longer credibly deny that climate change is real, human-caused, and a threat to our civilization. That means that the forces of inaction ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the fossil fuel interests and the front groups, organizations and mouthpieces-for-hire they fund ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ have been forced toturn to other tacticsin their effort to keep us dependent on fossil fuels.
These tactics includedeflection(focusing attention entirely on individual behavioral change so as to steer the societal discourse away from a discussion of the needed policies and systematic changes),division(getting climate advocates fighting with each rather than speakingnd the promotion ofdoomism(convincing some climate advocates that itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s too late to do anything anyway).
But the D-word du jour is delay. And weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve become all too familiar with the lexicon employed in its service: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½adaptation,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½resilience,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½geoengineeringï¿½ï¿½ï¿½and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½carbon capture.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ These words offer the soothing promise of action, but all fail to address the scale of the problem.
Adaptation and resilience are important. We must cope with the detrimental effects of climate change that are already baked in ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ coastal inundation and worse droughts, floods and other dangerous weather events. But if we fail to substantially reduce carbon emissions and stem the warming of the planet, we will exceed our collective adaptive capacity as a civilization.
Whenfossil fuel-friendlyRepublican Sen. Marco Rubiotells Floridiansthat they must simplyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½adaptï¿½ï¿½ï¿½to sea level rise (how? By growing fins and gills?), heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s trying to sty rhetoric and a license for polluters to continue with business as usual. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a delay tactic.
What about geoengineering? Should we engage in an enormous, unprecedented and uncontrolled experiment to further intervene with our planetary environment by, for example,shooting sulfur particulates into the stratosphereto block out the sun in hopes of somehow offsetting  the warming effect of increasing carbon pollution?
The law of unintended consequences almost certainly ensures that we willscrew up the planeteven more. The idea of geoengineering also grants license for continued carbon pollution. Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a reason Rex Tillerson, former ExxonMobil CEO and Donald Trumpï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s secretary of State, hasdismissedthe climate crisis as simply an ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½engineering problem.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ If we can simply clean up our act down the road, why not continue to burn fossil fuels? This, too, is a delay tactic ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ one that buys time for polluters to continue to make billions in profits as we mortgage the futwhat about ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½carbon captureï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and the promise of ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½net zeroï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ emissions by mid-century? Reaching zero emissions by 2050 will indeedbe necessaryto avert catastrophic planetary warming of more than 1.5 degrees Celsius. But it is hardly sufficient. We must also cut emissions in half by 2030 to hold warming below the danger limit of 1.5 degrees Celsius. Merely committing to the former, but not the latter, is like making a New Yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s resolution to lose 15 pounds without any plan to alter your diet and exercise regimen in the months ahead.
Furthermore, understand that the ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½netï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ in ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½net zeroï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ is doing quite a bit of work, for implicit in the word is the notion that we can continue to burn fossil fuels if we can find a way to remove them just as quickly. To quote Will Smithï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Genie in the movie ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Aladdin,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½a lot of gray areaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ in that word. It allows politicians to make vague promises of technolocarbon dioxide a year from the atmosphere in the future. Yet there is no precedent for deploying such technology on such a massive scale.
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s really easy to put carbon pollution into the atmosphere but really hard to take it back out and safely bury it for the long term. Nonetheless, the promise of carbon capture and net zero emissions decades from now allows politicians to kick the can so far down the road you can barely see it. Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s another masterful delay tactic.
Look no further than Australia, a country that deserves better than the feckless coalition government that currently reigns. The parties therehave reluctantly and conditionallyagreed only to the weak commitment of net zero emissions by mid-century. And their commitment to reduce carbon emissionby a paltry 26% to 28%by 2030 is half what other industrialized nations such as the U.S., Britain and the European Union have committed to.
A newly released report based on leaked documents shows that the Australian governmentsought to watcoming U.N. climate recommendation to phase out coal- and gas-fired power stations. Saudi Arabia and Russia ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ two countries thathave worked tosabotage international climate action in the past ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ have made a mockery of the current climate negotiations by agreeing onlyto a laughably delinquent2060 date for reaching net zero emissions.
Even countries that have made bold commitments are still suffering from an ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½implementation gapï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ that must be closed, a disconnect between what theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve promised and what theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re currently delivering. The Biden administration is currently hampered by Sen. Joe Manchin, acoal-state Democratwho stands in the way of the administrationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s clean energy agenda. The E.U. and Britain, meanwhile,are flirting withnew oil and gas pipelines even as the International Energy Agency has said there can beno new fossil fuel developmentif we are to avert catastrophic warming.
The U.N. climate summit in Glasgow can still lay outa path forward, if a re. But we cannot afford to fall victim to delay tactics. We must hold our policymakers accountable for representing the public interest rather than polluting interests. This is the last best opportunity for averting climate disaster.
Michael E. Mann is distinguished professor of atmospheric science and director of the Earth System Science Center at Penn State University. He is the author, most recently, of ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The New Climate War: The Fight to Take Back our Planet.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

column1: Net zero: Australiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Scott Morrison and his climate change balanci
column6:
MELBOURNE, Australiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Freak storms, catastrophic bushfires, debilitating drought. Australia knows about extreme weather.
But when hailstones recently struck northern Queensland, just as the governmentï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s junior party was debating a plan to reduce greenhouse emissions, it seemed like a sign from above. The 6-inch chunks of ice pounded cars and shattered windshields.
Days later, the government, with historic support from the junior National Party, endorsed Prime Minister Scott Morrisonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s goal of achieving net zero emissions in 2050. Morrison could be a leading voice to replace the worldï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s reliance on fossil fuels such as oil and gas with cleaner alternatives such as solar or hydrogen.
Instead, heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s headed to theUnited Nations Climate Change Conferencethat begins Sunday in Glasgow, Scotland, with a policy light on detail and soundly criticized by many Australians, from scientists to politicians, as leaving other countries to do the heavy lifting asgreenhouse gas emissing.
Australia wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t shut down coal or gas production or exports and there will be no job losses in farming, mining or gas as a result of the international push to address climate change, Morrison told reporters while presenting the plan.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s an energy, trade and economic plan, not just an environmental plan,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It is not a revolution, but a careful evolution to take advantage of changes in our markets.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Australian coal not only contributes to the emissions produced domestically, but its fossil fuel export industry ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ one of the largest in the world ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ contributes to emissions produced by other countries. It ranks last of 31 wealthy developed countries for its emission performance, according to the research groupClimate Council.
Net zero refers to balancing the greenhouse gas emissions going into and coming out of the atmosphere.
Australiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s current 2030 target aims to cut emissions byï¿½ï¿½ï¿½26%-28% below 2005 levels, a target thson said his country is on track to beat the target and reduce emissions by 30% to 35%. Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s considerably short of the 50%-52% target ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½announced byPresident Bidenin April for U.S. emissions by 2030.
While Australia is a big exporter of carbon-rich fossil fuels, it is also a big and growing exporter of low-carbon new-energy metals needed to replace fossil fuels. It is well placed to benefit from growing demand for metals such as nickel, copper, lithium and cobalt.
Government subsidies for solar energy have led to Australians adopting rooftop solar panels so enthusiastically that the grid operator has had to bring forward plans to upgrade the grid to prevent blackouts.
But adoption of electric vehicles, which can lead to lower carbon emissions, trails other developed nations even though Australia is the worldï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s biggest exporter of the lithium used in the batteries of vehicles.
When he left for Glasgow on Thursday, Morrison fended off a suggestion from the UK hosts of the conference, knAustralia make a more ambitious contribution to the 2030 target.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve got a plan for Australia. Theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve got a plan for the UK,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Morrison said.
Morrison has been seen as a supporter of the fossil fuel industry at least since February 2017, when, as treasurer, he brandished a lump of coal in Parliament and told lawmakers how the mineral had made Australia one of the wealthiest countries in the world.
The former marketing executive ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ derisively called ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Scotty from marketingï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ by his critics ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ won leadership of the conservative Liberal Party and the government when Prime Minister Malcom Turnbull was deposed in a party room battle in 2018. Morrison led the party to a narrow victory in 2019, in part on a promise to take a cautious approach to climate change policies.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½What is important is that I act consistent with the mandate I had from the Australian people,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he told reporters.  ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½They rejected a 45% target at the last electiot weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve done.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In the run up to the climate change conference, politicians, comedians and princes have urged Australia to do more. Comedian Dan Ilic crowdfunded a campaign to take out advertisements in Times Square, mocking Australiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s track record; Prince Charles diplomatically urged Morrison to attend COP26.
The net zero plan Morrison is taking to Glasgow will not look impressive among the 38 nations in the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, said Jeremy Moss, a professor of political philosophy at the University of New South Wales.
This ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½last-minute commitment to net zero will leave Australia more closely aligned with Saudi Arabia than the U.S. and Europe,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Moss said, referring to the Middle Eastern country that is the worldï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s biggest oil exporter. Saudi Arabia has said it will reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2060 although it doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t plan to stop producing oil.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Australia has lost an opportunity to show how a wealthyendence on fossil fuel exports,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Moss said.
Apart from not shutting down coal and gas, Morrisonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s plan pledges $20 billion in technology investments expected to unlock at least $80 billion of private and public investment in clean hydrogen, carbon capture and storage and energy storage.
Mike Cannon-Brookes, the Australian U.S.-based billionaire and co-founder of software company Atlassian, said Australiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s plan paled in comparison to the UK proposal, which details pathways for every sector to 2037.
Morrisonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s plan is meaningless without strong action this decade, Simon Bradshaw, the head of research at the Climate Council, said in an email. The organization favors Australia reducing its emissions by 75% by 2030.
When Morrison says his strategy is about ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½technology, not taxes,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a reference to the legacy of the impact of climate change policies on Australian politics. Policies to reduce emissions ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ like a carbon emissions trading scheme or a ca threat to jobs and incomes that could cost them votes in elections.
Morrison became prime minister after Turnbullï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s plan for an energy and climate change policy made Turnbull unpopular within his party.
National Party support, stemming from the vast Australian countryside where mining and farming are strongholds, is crucial for Morrison if he is to win an election due in the next 12 months. The partnership between the Liberal Party Morrison now leads and the Nationals has lasted 75 years.
The opposition Labor Party led Morrisonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Coalition 54%-46% in a poll published in the Australian newspaper in late October.
Representatives of Australiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s most popular European car, Volkswagen, say it is becoming the biggest seller of affordable EVs everywhere but in Australia because of the governmentï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s failure to adopt tighter restrictions on vehicle emissions such as those required in Europe.
Australia is ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½an automotive dumping ground for auto engines that our competitors cannot  Volkswagen Australiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Managing Director Michael Barstch. The continued lack of federal leadership on EVs and its aversion to setting emissions targets means ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Australia languishes in the automotive third world,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.
The Australian governmentï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s climate approach, even after the National Partyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s endorsement of Morrisonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s plan, means it risks being left behind, particularly as other regions act more resolutely and investment increasingly seeks ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½greenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ criteria, some observers say.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The advantage of adopting meaningful 2030 emission reduction targets now is that the economy wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t be littered with stranded fossil fuel assets in the future,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Moss said.
Petrakis is a special correspondent.

column1: Sean Pennï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s CORE group faces labor charges over impassioned internal
column6:
The National Labor Relations Board has filed a formal complaint against actor Sean Pennï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s nonprofit disaster response organization over claims that Penn implicitly threatened employees who criticized conditions at aDodger Stadium COVID-19 vaccination site.
The lawyer who brought the charges said an internal email from Penn to his employees amounted to coercive conduct that could negatively affect young workers. Lawyers for the Oscar-winning actor are insisting that the claims are frivolous and without merit and are calling for their dismissal.
Pennï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s nonprofit group, Community Organized Relief Effort, or CORE, assisted the city of Los Angeles at the mass vaccination site in January, earning praise for taking action during a critical moment in the pandemic when the city wastransitioning from testing to vaccination.
But Penn and CORE quickly came under scrutiny after two anonymous commenters left disparaging remarks on a New York Times message board about the working hours and food provisions athe comments spurred Penn to write an impassioned, 2,200-word email in which hechastised the commenters.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½And to whoever authored these, understand that in every cell of my body is a vitriol for the way your actions reflect so harmfully upon your brothers and sisters in arms,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Penn wrote in the email, which was promptly leaked to The Times. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I have taken counsel and here will refrain from using the words with which I would otherwise choose to describe the character of your actions.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The email also encouraged those who were unwilling to do the work to quit.
California
Sean Penn strikes back after two people who claim to work for his nonprofit assisting at the Dodger Stadium vaccination site criticize the operation.
The words caught the eye of Los Angeles labor lawyer Daniel B. Rojas, who petitioned  the NLRB to investigate whether the remarks constituted an unlawful threat.
Rojas said Friday that he was particularly concerned because many of COREï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s employees at Dodger Stadle of color.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½When I read Mr. Pennï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s letter, I flagged the contents as unlawful and became upset about the notion that, due to the impetuous conduct of an ultra-wealthy man, hundreds of young people in L.A. would be coerced into believing that discussing wages or working conditions with third parties is incompatible with continued employment in the nonprofit sector,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said via email.
The NLRBï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s complaint, dated Oct. 25, sided with  Rojas, charging that Penn had ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½impliedly threatenedï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ employees with reprisals and discharge during his screed.
But Penn and CORE are pushing back. Their attorney, Mathew Rosengart, confirmed Friday that the group refused a settlement offer with the NLRB based on the ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½utter lack of legal meritï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ of the charges, and noted that no CORE employees or unions protested Pennï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s statements.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½CORE and Mr. Penn completely stand by his email, and the NLRBï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s actions to distract CORE from its crucial mission d in a statement, adding that the group will ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½vigorously contest and fight the baseless charge in the legal system.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Rosengart said the comments from Pennï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s email were ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½cherry-pickedï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and failed to account for the larger context, which also included ample praise for COREï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s employees and vivid descriptions of Pennï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s own distress during the deadly winter surge of COVID-19.

ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We usuallybway, but ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½the same old lettuce wraps every day.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The other, a self-described CORE staff member, said that in order to comply with Mayor Eric Garcettiï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s push to switch the siteï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s operations from COVID-19 tests to vaccinations, employees worked 18-hour days, six days per week, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½without the opportunity to take breaks,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a claim Pennï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s camp denied.

ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You rose up. You did. Not me. All of you. And I will admit something. It made me weep. Not with some stupid self-presumed sense of fatherly pride, but simply a human pride in experiencing that people like you exist,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he wrote.

These are our tax dollars at work.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

column1: Glasgow is the moment to go big on climate change. But Biden is stymied by Congress
column6:
Over the summer, as the world reeled from record-breaking heat waves, flooding and wildfires, the United Nations issueda climate change reportthat connected the dots with terrifying clarity.
The world has moved too slowly to stop global warming and the increase in extreme and deadly weather events. But with radical action to cut carbon emissions over the next decade, we can still prevent the worst devastation.
Next week will test if world leaders are ready to act with the urgency this moment requires. Government officials, business leaders and environmentalists will gather in Glasgow, Scotland, for a two-week summit tohammer out new commitmentsto slash planet-warming emissions.
The COP26 conference is expected to be the most important climate event since 2015, when global leaders met in Paris and promised to cut their greenhouse gas emissions enough to stop the planet from warming more than 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial times. But nations havenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t done nearly enough to meet the Paris agreemeget, so at this follow-up conference in Glasgow, world leaders will be expected to present concrete plans for how they intend to fulfill the promise.
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not that people donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t care about global warming. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s just that they donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t seem to care in rational proportion to the enormity of the problem.
As of now, the Biden administration is going to Scotland with a weak plan that mostly relies on incentives to encourage emissions reductions but without the mandates or penalties to ensure the reductions actually happen ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ all because obstructionists and fossil fuel loyalists in Congress gutted President Bidenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s most aggressive climate change programs.
Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a disappointment because all eyes will be on the United States. President Biden has laid out an ambitious climate change agenda, including a goal to cut the nationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s greenhouse gas emissions  50% from 2005 levels by 2030. But the U.S. will never meet that target on pledges alone. It will take aggressn fossil fuels to keep the lights on, power vehicles and heat homes.
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s deeply frustrating that one of the most important pieces of Bidenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s climate agenda ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a plan to reward utility companies that use clean energy sources and penalize those that donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ was yanked from the Build Back Better bill to coax a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½yesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ vote from  Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin III from the coal-producing state of West Virginia. (Not a single Republican is expected to vote for the spending package, so Manchinï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s support is essential. So much for theConservative Climate Caucus.)
Instead, Bidenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sBuild Back Better plannow relies on $555 billion in tax credits and incentives to encourage companies and consumers to invest in clean energy. That will still be a huge help. If passed, it would be the largest single federal investment in climate change in history. Biden said all that spending could get the U.S. to hit its climate targets. (Though someexperts are skepticalthe cs
Thousands will attend the U.N. global climate summit. While hopes for a major breakthrough are slim, hereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s what leaders hope to get done.
While Congress is inching closer to approving the Build Back Better planï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s tax credits and temporary spending, the nation really needs laws and programs that require utilities and energy companies to rapidly phase out fossil fuels. Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve seen what happens when Congress refuses to be more aggressive.President Obama had to rely on incentives, executive orders and slow-moving regulatory processesto tackle climate change. But those efforts were rolled back by President Trump and the U.S. lost critical time and credibility in fighting global warming.
This is the moment when the worldï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s industrialized nations need to step up with real policies and programs that make real reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. The U.S. is doing a lot, but if the world is going to avoid greater devastation from climate change, we need to be doing much more, muchcommon opinion

Waynepreviously told reportersthat he thought Planckï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s disappearance could be connected to her job as a financial controller at Camden Capital Partners. The LAPD has ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½really dug deep, and Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve got to take a back seat and let them do their job,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.
Police said they have no information on a suspect.
Aerial footage of the Chiquita Canyon Landfill on Monday showed heavy machinery digging amid the dry dirt.
Landfill officials said in a statement that they were ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½fully cooperating with investigatorsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and following all health and safety protocols.
Wayne said that ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s somebody out there for sureï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ who knows what happened and that he hoped anyone with information would come forward.

A single-story home on a quiet street in Lancaster became a scene of tragedy Sunday night when a father shot and killed his four children and their grandmother, authorities said.

When they arrived, they found four children ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ all age 12 or younger ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and a woman in her 50s, all with gunshot wounds to their upper bodies.

column1: To protest COVID mandates, this California town declared itself a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½constitutional repub
column6:
OROVILLE, Calif.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½For Oroville Vice Mayor Scott Thomson, the father of two young boys, Gov. Gavin Newsomï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s mandaterequiring schoolchildren to be vaccinatedagainst COVID-19 was the final straw.
He believed the government had no right to tell him what to put into his, or his childrenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s, bodies. Many of his constituents agreed when it came to pandemic mandates.
And so, he came up with a grandiose, headline-grabbing nom de guerre for his small Northern California city.
Oroville declared itself a constitutional republic. A place where the local leaders pledge to fight mandates they say go too far.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Any executive orders issued by the State of California or by the United States federal government that are overreaching or clearly violate our constitutionally protected rights will not be enforced by the City of Oroville against its citizens,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ readthe declarationpassed this month by the City Council.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The desire here is dialogue,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Thomson said.
For some, the s in town saw it as a reckless tantrum amid an ongoing pandemic that has killedmore than 73,000 Californians.
Butte County, population about 220,000, has one of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½slowest vaccination rates. As of Saturday, 47% of its residents were fully vaccinated, compared with 64% of all Californians.
Butte Countyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s largest hospital, the 298-bed Enloe Medical Center in Chico, has averaged 26 COVID-19 patients over the last week ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½more than all but one hospitalin Los Angeles County, home to 10 million people.
Oroville resident Celia Hirschman lost her father, former San Francisco poet laureateJack Hirschman, to COVID-19 three months ago. She said the resolution insults people who have lost loved ones or are immunocompromised, just to score political points.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It says weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re cowboys, and weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re not going to live by your rules,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t think itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s about open dialogue at all. I feel itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a dangerous measure that they have no now one of a growing number of rural California communities in recent years to label itself a sanctuary or a place otherwise exempt from some liberal ideal.
Two years ago, the desert town of Needles becamea ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sanctuary cityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ for the 2nd Amendmentin a rebuke of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s strict gun-control laws. And in defiance of pandemic shutdown orders, the Central Valley towns of Atwater and Coalinga last year declared themselves, respectively, a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sanctuary city for businessï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and a town where all businesses are essential ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ with bothlosing emergency COVID-19 fundingin the process.
Designed to benefit from the buzz of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sanctuaryï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ designations used in the context of protecting undocumented immigrants, the labels reflect tensions between rural towns andthe Newsom administrationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and the left in general.
Orovilleï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s constitutional republic resolution is mostly symbolic, with no power over schools, which are regulated by the stawhere 36% of voters are registered Republicans, 35% are registered Democrats, and 20% are independents. By close margins, the county voted for President Trump in 2016 and President Biden last year. Voters heresupportedthe attempted recall of Newsom.
COVID rates have remained relatively high here, even as they eased significantly in places like Los Angeles and San Francisco. The number of COVID-positive patients during the Delta variant surge, most of whom were unvaccinated, peaked at Enloe Medical Center on Sept. 23, when there were 95 people hospitalized with the virus. Now, the new Omicron variant looms as a potential threat.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This is a difficult place to be, going into the winter,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Marcia Nelson, the hospitalï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s chief medical officer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re not starting from a baseline of under 10 patients; weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re starting from a baseline of what used to feel like a really high number.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
At theOroville City Council meetingat which the constitutional republic resolularify to one commenter that the resolution was not ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½beginning the effort for Oroville to secede from California and from the Union.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
One speaker was an older man who compared the resolution to the decades-oldState of Jefferson movement, which calls for Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s rural, conservative northern counties to secede and form their own state.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½These ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½constitutional republicï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ people would probably prevent mask mandates,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the man said, citing the countyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s vaccination rate. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½In other words, theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re looking to kill people.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The audience broke out in laughter. When the resolution passed, they cheered.
Thomson said the impetus for the declaration was vaccine mandates, especially the one for schoolchildren, which has been opposed bymultiple Butte County school districtsand has sparked protests across the state, includingin cities like Los Angeles.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Now that the mandates have gone from not just putting something on the outsidemething inside your body that nobody knows the long-term effects of, thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s just like, OK, now youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re, in my opinion, crossing the line,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Thomson said.
Thomson, the pastor of an Assembly of God church, said he is not anti-mask or opposed to the vaccine for people who want it. He said he and his sons are not vaccinated but that they now have antibodies after a mild bout with COVID-19 in August.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½There are people out there who are like, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This whole thing is a hoax,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Thomson said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We are not like that, just being reckless.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
He said that unvaccinated city employees are tested weekly for COVID-19 at the cityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s expense. And his church has handed out hundreds of masks to congregants.
Council members said they have been inundated with calls and emails about the resolution ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ positive and negative ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ from across the country.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s been a lot of expletives,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Eric Smith, a councilman and presid declaration. He said the broad pandemic closures were a hard pill to swallow because they came amid what has been a local ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½fiscal renaissanceï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and growing population in recent years.
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s been ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½a tightrope,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said, to have ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½a balanced approach to concerns about the disease and spread and peopleï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s livelihoods.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Councilwoman Krysi Riggs said she cast the sole no vote against the declaration because she believed the best way for city leaders to push back against mandates is through the judicial system, not through a resolution. But, she said, she understands the frustration with the mandates.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve been in this situation for 20 months, and I think the general feeling is fatigue,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½When does this come to an end? Yes, there are some lights at the end of the tunnel, but those come with uncertainties and risks as well.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The pandemic, she said, added to what has already been five years of disaster for to mass evacuations; the 2018 Camp fire in nearby Paradise;the droughtthat forcedthe shutdownof a major hydroelectric power plant at Lake Oroville in August.
When wildfires broke outacross Butte County last summer, the smoky air in Oroville was toxic ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ but indoor dining was banned across the state because of the virus, leaving local restaurants in a bind, Riggs said.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s been a yo-yo of whatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s acceptable and what isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said.
Brian Wong, who opened the Union Bar & Grill in Oroville in fall 2019, said he thought the cityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s statement about the mandates was ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½very courageous.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As a small-business owner, Wong said he felt like he had to navigate complicated and ever-changing state rules on his own.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You felt angry, you felt weak. For a whole year, it was nothing but fear and anger going through this whole system,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Seeing politics creep into all of it, it felt like they were not being sincere about healt Tong Fong Low, said he spent a lot of money to build a patio for outdoor dining and required his dozens of employees to wear masks for more than a year, until vaccines became widely available.
He has heard all views about the pandemic from his customers and said he welcomes diverse perspectives. Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s why he named his restaurant Union, because itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s his vision of California: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½a coming together of all these different people to make up the whole.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Parked down the street from Union, Joseph Tomlinson, a 24-year-old chef, said he opened his burger truck, Joeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Lunch ToGo, in March 2020, just as the pandemic was starting.
Tomlinson had not heard much about the constitutional republic declaration, but he figured it couldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t hurt if it pushed for more local control. He said when he and his employees masked up and required social distancing, he received no harassment from customers.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We never had any Karens,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We are a small town, and wown antique store, Gold City Mercantile, Michael Suplita laughed and rolled his eyes when asked about Oroville being a constitutional republic. He responded with a quintessential ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½dadï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ joke: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½As far as Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m concerned, a mandate is when two men go out to dinner.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As for the declaration?
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s all just talk,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Suplita said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re the new city that says, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have to do whatever you say.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Sure, OK.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

column1: ýýýSo many memoriesýýý: Over 500 homes feared destroyed by Colorado fire
column6:
SUPERIOR, Colo.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½One couple returned home Friday to find the mailbox about the only thing left standing. Charred cars and a burned trampoline lay outside smoldering houses. On some blocks, homes reduced to smoking ruins stood next to ones all but unscathed by the flames.
Colorado residents driven from their neighborhoods by a terrifying, wind-whipped wildfire got their first, heartbreaking look at the damage the morning after, while others could only wait and wonder whether their homes were among the more than 500 feared destroyed.
At least seven people were injured, but there were no immediate reports of deaths or missing people in the aftermath of theblaze outside Denver.
Cathy Glaab found her home in the town of Superior where she lives with her husband had been turned into a pile of charred and twisted debris. It was one of seven houses in a row that burned to the ground.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The mailbox is standing,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Glaab said, trying to crack a smile through tears. She added sadly, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Sohe devastation, she said they intended to rebuild the house they have had since 1998. They love that the land backs up to a natural space, and they have a view of the mountains from the back.
Rick Dixon feared there would be nothing to return to after he saw firefighters try to save his burning home on the news. On Friday, Dixon, his wife and 21-year-old son found it mostly gutted with a gaping hole in the roof but still standing. Only smoldering rubble remained where several homes once stood in a row immediately next to theirs.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We thought we lost everything,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said, as he held his mother-in-lawï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s china in padded containers. They also retrieved sculptures that belonged to Dixonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s father and piles of clothes still on hangers.
The wildfire erupted Thursday in and around Louisville and Superior, neighboring towns about 20 miles northwest of Denver with a combined population of 34,000.
Tens of thousands were ordered to flee as the flames, propelled by gusts up to 105 mph, swept ighborhoods with alarming speed.
At a Costco in Superior, two store employees came running toward the checkout lines, one of them shouting, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Everyone evacuate, evacuate, evacuate!ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Katrina Peterson, who was inside.
A video she made showed dark skies and whirling debris outside. The falling ash filled her ears, and she had to squint to keep it from getting in her eyes. The store was left standing.
The cause of the blaze was under investigation. Emergency authorities said utility officials found no downed power lines around where the fire broke out.
With some roads still closed Friday, people walked to their homes to get clothes or medicine, turn the water off to prevent the pipes from freezing, or to see whether they still had a house. They left carrying backpacks and pulling suitcases or wagons down the sidewalk.
David Marks stood on a hillside overlooking Superior with others, using a borrowed pair of binoculars and a long camera lens to see whether his house, and those of his neighbors,there, but he couldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t tell for sure whether his place was OK. He said at least three friends lost their homes.
He had watched from the hillside as the neighborhood burned.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½By the time I got up here, the houses were completely engulfed,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I mean, it happened so quickly. Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve never seen anything like that. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Just house after house, fences, just stuff flying through the air, just caught on fire.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
By first light Friday, the towering flames that had lit up the night sky had subsided and the winds had died down. Light snow soon began to fall, and the blaze, which burned at least 9.4 square miles, was no longer considered an immediate threat.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We might have our very own New Yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s miracle on our hands if it holds up that there was no loss of life,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Gov. Jared Polis said, noting that many people had just minutes to evacuate.
The fire broke out unusually late in the year, following an extremely dry fall and amid a winter nearly  more than 500 homes were probably destroyed. He and the governor said as many as 1,000 homes might have been lost, though that wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t be known until crews can assess the damage.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s unbelievable when you look at the devastation that we donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have a list of 100 missing persons,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the sheriff said.
The sheriff said some communities were reduced to just ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½smoking holes in the ground.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ He urged residents to wait for the all-clear to go back because of the danger of fire and fallen power lines.
Sarah Owens, her husband, adult son and their dog got out of their Superior home within 10 minutes of learning about the evacuation from a Facebook post. But as everyone tried leaving by way of the winding streets of the well-to-do Rock Creek neighborhood, it took them 90 minutes to go two miles.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The good news is I think our house may be OK,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Owens said.
But from now on, she said, she plans to have a bag packed in case of another fire.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I neverýý Owens said. ýýýI want to stay here. No matter where you live, there are always going to be natural disasters.ýýý
Superior and Louisville are filled with middle- and upper-middle-class subdivisions with shopping centers, parks and schools. The area is between Denver and Boulder, home to the University of Colorado.
Scientists sayclimate change is making weather more extremeandwildfires more frequent and destructive.
Ninety percent of Boulder County is in severe or extreme drought, and it hasnýýýt seen substantial rainfall since mid-summer.Denver set a record for consecutive days without snowbefore it got a small storm on Dec. 10, its last snowfall before the wildfires broke out.
Bruce and Mary Janda faced the loss of their Louisville home of 25 years in person Friday after learning it had been destroyed through a neighborýýýs photos.
ýýýWe knew that the house was totaled, but I felt the need to see it, see what the rest of the neighborhood looked like,ýýý Bruce Janda said. ýýýWeýýýre a very close-knit community on this street. We all know each other and we all love each other. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s hard to see this happen to all of us.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Associated Press writer Thomas Peipert contributed to this report.

column1: Is wildfire arson getting worse in California? Climate change doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
column6:
A college professor. A Caltech grad. A woman in a bikini. And, just this month, a father and son.
A confounding collection of Californians have been accused of contributing to one of the worst wildfire seasons in state history ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a season that saw three killed, thousands of homes leveled and more than 2.5 million acres burned.
While fires ignited by downed power lines and lightning have caused widespread destruction in recent years, this last wildfire season was unusual for the number of large fires that were linked to arson. Wildfire arson arrests have been climbing over the last few years: In 2021, the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection reported 140 arrests by its  law enforcement division ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ 20 more than last year anddouble the numberof 2019.
To some, the apparent surge in arson incidents has been a troubling new development in Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ever-worsening wildfire regime, and it has even given rise to a raft of conspiracy theories. Yet experts say the attention-grab uptick in arrests belie an enduring truth: Arson represents only a fraction of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s fire starts each year.
What has changed, they say, is that bone-dry drought conditions and overgrown forests have enabled even the smallest of sparks toexplode into an inferno.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Once they put that fire on the ground, they have no control over how it will grow,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Gianni Muschetto, chief of Cal Fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s law enforcement division.
California
After David Scott Smith and his son, Travis Shane Smith, were arrested a day earlier, prosecutors filed several felony charges against them Thursday.
In California, lawmakers distinguish between two types of arson: willful, malicious arson and reckless arson, such as when a person sets off fireworks in dry brush, Muschetto said. Identifying the source of a wildfire is one of the more technical jobs in law enforcement, and in 2019 ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the most recent year for which he had data ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the causes of the majority of Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wildfiresccounted for about 12% and lightning  6%.
But arson was also a factor, sparking about 9% of fires in 2019, and roughly 8% to 10% of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wildfires in any given year. In 2021, when Cal Fire responded to more than 8,600 fires, that could mean as many as 800 blazes.
One of the alleged arsonists who made national headlines this year was Gary Maynard, a former college professor linked to anï¿½ï¿½ï¿½arson-setting spreeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½near the site of the Dixie fire, thesecond-largest wildfirein Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s recorded history.
Maynard was charged with willfully starting four fires in the Shasta-Trinity and Lassen national forests in July and August. Some of the blazes were set behind fire lines and in evacuation zones, with investigators in one instance identifying sticks, newspaper material and a wooden match in a burned area on the ground.
He has pleaded not guilty to all charges, his attorney said via email.
Witnesses at the scene said Maynard appeared to be mentally unstable. Officials confirmed trked at two California universities, where he taught seminars in criminology and criminal justice.
California
Gary Stephen Maynard, 47, has been charged with willfully starting the Ranch fire and has been linked to at least six other blazes.
The circumstances around Maynard and other arson suspects prompted a wave of speculation among far-right groups and conspiracy theorists, with some falsely suggesting thatmembers of Antifawere intentionally setting fires as part of an elaborate political plot.
But the motives for arson are more complex than that, said Glenn Corbett, an associate professor of fire science and public administration at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s dozens of reasons why people start fires,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Corbett said, listing examples such as malice, recklessness, revenge, mental health issues or even just ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½bad behavior.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The latest string of high-profile cases ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½to some extent trend with social upheaval,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Corbett said, including l and economic divides. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Sometimes those end up being ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½trigger eventsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ that sort of release people to do things that they probably wouldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t normally do.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
But arson-related fires are especially dangerous given the record-setting heat and drought across the West, which have dried the landscape and primed it to burn ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ leading tofaster, hotter and more intense wildfiresthan ever before.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The volume, the size, the ferocity of fire is tied directly to whatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s burning,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Corbett said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½High levels of dryness and low levels of humidity and no rain ... thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a prime situation for having a fire, and certainly one that is very difficult to contain.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
California
The dryness of the vegetation, primed by both long-term drought and shorter-term heat waves, is making it easy for fires to ignite and even easier for them to spread.
One blaze that quickly grew out of control was theFawn fire in Shasta County,which was allegedly ignitedties say was found with CO2 cartridges and a lighter near where the fire ignited.
The fire grew quickly amid dry timber and heavy winds. By the end of its 10-day run, it had injured three firefighters, destroyed 185 buildings and charred more than 8,500 acres.
In December, Souverneva was ordered to a state mental hospital after a judge found hermentally unfit to stand trial.Her attorney did not respond to a request for comment.
But legal experts say her case and others like it raise important questions about how the state responds to instances of arson, which often involve external factors such as homelessness, mental health and drug use.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The issue is not whether the punishment fits the crime ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s that the punishment of incarceration doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t necessarily get to the root of the problem,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Louis Shapiro, a defense attorney and former public defender in Los Angeles.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Most arsonists have mental health issues which, if were timely treated, would avoid the arsonhe said. The ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½government needs to get ahead of these issues and proactively help those with mental health issues, rather than react to the damage after the fact. That is where the focus needs to be.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Joel Dvoskin, a forensic psychologist who has studied arson, said itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s important to distinguish between people with mental disabilities and people experiencing emotional crises.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½When people do arson thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s only intended to cause destruction, thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a despairing thing to do, and we live in a time when a lot of people are experiencing fear, anger and despair,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Those are the three emotions that cause so much damage in our world, and I doubt that arson is an exception.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Like Shapiro, he said incarceration isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t always the answer, particularly since the reasons for committing arson are so varied and complex.
In California, the penalties for arson can include fines or several years of imprisonment. Shapiro said the outcomes of canited by apyrotechnic device at a gender-reveal partyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ are harder to predict and largely depend on the way the sentencing judge views the case.
That fire, dubbed the El Dorado fire, went on to burn more than 22,000 acres andkill a firefighter.
California
Alexandra Souverneva has been charged with felony arson and committing arson during a state of emergency.
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s an example of the kind of blaze that might have sputtered in a wetter climate but instead fed on hot, dry conditions that turned it into a monster, said Ed Nordskog, an arson investigator and co-author of ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Arson Investigation in the Wildland.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The fuel is so dry because of the climate, and of course if thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s any sort of wind, that fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s gone off to the races,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.
Still, what seems like a trend of arson in California may not actually reflect an increase in the number of people setting fires. California has more arson investigators than any other state and is becoming more profices such as Colorado that may seem to have fewer instances of arson donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have as many investigators contributing to their statistics, he said.
Dmitry Gorin, a defense attorney and former prosecutor, similarly emphasized that the numbers remain small.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re seeing a lot of [cases] in the news now, and they usually happen during the fire season when itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s dry with high winds, so we hear about them,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Gorin said, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½but as a matter of percentage of criminal cases in court, theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re pretty rare, even in California.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Some arsonists are easier to catch than others, such as the woman who admitted to starting a fire near South Lake Tahoe in August after sheemerged from the scenein a bikini and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½covered in scratches and soot.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Other cases are more complicated, including the large number of fires that are started by people living in the wildland-urban interface or people struggling with mental health issues and drug use, Nordskog said.
But in ýýýEvery fire has the potential to be a giant megafire.ýýý
California
New study says climate change is essentially two-thirds to 88% responsible for the conditions driving wildfire woes in the western United States.
Earlier this month, prosecutors filed reckless-arson and firearm chargesagainst David and Travis Smith,a father and son suspected of starting theCaldor firenear South Lake Tahoe. That blaze, along with the Dixie fire, became the first to ever burnfrom one side of the Sierra to the other,and leveled the Gold Rush-era mountain town ofGrizzly Flats.
The Smithsýýý attorney, Mark Reichel, said via email that they are ýýý100% innocentýýý and even called for help as soon as they spotted the fire. They intend to beat all charges, he said.
But the outcome of the case wonýýýt do much to budge statistics. Of the 140 arson arrests this year, only 29 were in the ýýýrecklessýýý category while 111 were willful, said Muschetto of Cal Fire. The agency issued about 360 citations for fire and fireworks violations this year.
Still, the confluence of cases and conditions is undeniably creating more challenges for the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s residents and for those trying to protect them from the worst effects of wildfire.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Whether itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s an accidental act or lightning or arson, that risk of those fires getting larger quicker is increasing with climate change,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Muschetto said.

column1: Newsom declares storm-related state of emergency in 20 counties, including L.A.
column6:
Gov. Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency in 20 California counties on Thursday as winter storms continued to lash the state with record snow and rainfall that have knocked out power, shut down major roads and freeways, and caused debris flows, among other hazards.
According to the proclamation, the following counties are under a state of emergency: Alameda, Amador, Calaveras, El Dorado, Humboldt, Lake, Los Angeles, Marin, Monterey, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Placer, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Luis Obispo, San Mateo, Santa Cruz, Sierra and Yuba.
The emergency proclamation will support response and recovery efforts after the storms, including by expanding access to state resources under the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Disaster Assistance Act, according to a statement by Newsomï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s office.
California
With more than 5 inches of rain in December and counting, Los Angeles played host to another winter storm that promises to bring even more moisture to the area through New Yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Eve.
It directs the CaliforTransportation to request immediate help through the Federal Highway Administrationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Emergency Relief Program for highway repairs or reconstruction and eases access to unemployment benefits for residents who lose their jobs because of the storms.
In Los Angeles, the slow-moving storm caused multiple road and highway closures and triggered evacuations near wildfire burn scars.

Firefighters rescued at least 50 people from the Leo Carrillo State Park campground in Malibu after rainfall sent a torrent of muddy water through the area, and accumulating ice and snow forced officials to close a portion of the Grapevine in both directions of the 5 Freeway for several hours.
Travelers at downtown L.A.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Union Station were sent scrambling in the morning as several inches of water filled at least one hallway.
In the Sieing snowfall brought communities to a standstill as storms cut power to tens of thousands of residents and officials urged residents and visitors to stay off mountain roads until conditions improve.

The 2.34 inches of rain in downtown L.A. broke a daily record set in 1936 as the storm led to flash floods, debris flows and closed highways and roads.

column1: Colorado wildfires burn hundreds of homes and force evacuations
column6:
DENVERï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½An estimated 580 homes, a hotel and a shopping center have burned and tens of thousands of people were evacuated in wind-fueled wildfires outside Denver, officials said Thursday evening.
Boulder County Sheriff Joe Pelle said one injury has been reported and he didnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t rule out the possibility of more injuries or deaths to come given the intensity of fires that quickly swept across the region as winds gusted up to 105 mph.
The first fire erupted just before 10:30 a.m. and was ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½attacked pretty quickly and laid down later in the day and is currently being monitored,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ with no structures lost, Pelle said.
A second wildfire, reported just after 11 a.m., ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ballooned and spread rapidly east,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Pelle said. The blaze spans 2.5 square miles and has engulfed parts of the area in smoky, orangish skies and sent residents scrambling to get to safety.
Thursday nightï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wind activity will determine when crews are able to go in and begin assessing the damage and  of fire we canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t fight head on,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Pelle said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We actually had deputy sheriffs and firefighters in areas that had to pull out because they just got overrun.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The city of Louisville, which has a population of about 21,000, was ordered to evacuate after all 13,000 residents in Superior were told to leave. The neighboring towns are roughly 20 miles northwest of Denver.
Several blazes started in the area Thursday, at least some sparked by downed power lines.
Six people who were injured in the fires were being treated at UCHealth Broomfield Hospital, spokesperson Kelli Christensen said. A nearby portion of U.S. Highway 36 was shut down.
Coloradoï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Front Range, where most of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s population lives, had an extremely dry and mild fall, and winter so far has continued to be mostly dry. Snow was expected Friday in the region, though.
Video captured by a bystander outside a Superior Costco store showed winds whipping through trees in the parking lot surrounded by grascattered across the ground.
World & Nation
As states agree to leave more water in the Colorado River reservoir, Native tribes get more involved after a history of being left on the water management sidelines.
Leah Angstman and her husband saw similar skies while returning to their Louisville home from Denver International Airport after being away for the holidays. As they were sitting on the bus going toward Boulder, Angstman recalled leaving clear blue skies and abruptly entering clouds of brown and yellow smoke.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The wind rocked the bus so hard that I thought the bus would tip,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she wrote in a message to the Associated Press.
The visibility was so poor that the bus had to pull over, and they waited a half-hour until a regional transit authority van escorted them to a turnaround on the highway. There she saw four fires burning in bushes across the highway, she said.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The sky was dark, dark brown, and the dirt was blowing in swirls across the sidewalk like snakes,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said.
C best we can hope for is incremental progress ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ two steps forward, one step back, a string of little victories.
Angstman ended up evacuating, getting in a car with her husband and driving northeast without knowing where they would end up.
Vignesh Kasinath, an assistant professor of biochemistry at the University of Colorado in Boulder, evacuated from a neighborhood in Superior with his wife and her parents. Kasinath said the family was overwhelmed because of the sudden evacuation warning and anxious from the chaos while trying to leave.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s only because I am active on Twitter I came to know about this,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Kasinath, who said he did not receive an official evacuation notice from authorities.
The fires prompted Gov. Jared Polis to declare a state of a emergency, allowing the state to access disaster emergency funds.
The evacuations come as climate change ismaking weather more extremeand wildfires more frequent and destructive, scientists say.A historic drought and heat waveshr to fight in the U.S. West.

column1: Standing room only: Balboa Island Ferry to be closed to vehicles for most of January
column6:
Motorists hoping to visit or leave Newport Beachï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Balboa Island will have to take the long way around next month as the Balboa Island Ferry will temporarily close to vehicles.
Beginning Jan. 3, the century-old ferry, which carries vehicles and passengers through Newport Bay from the Balboa Peninsula to the island and back, will be open to foot and bike traffic only as the city begins electrical work on the islandï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Agate Avenue, where the ferry terminal is located.
The work is part of a $6.2-million utility ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½undergroundingï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ project, which will bury overhead power and other utility lines, Newport Beach assistant city engineer Mike Sinacori told the Orange County Register.
Construction is slated to end Jan. 28, according to the ferryï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s social media page.
The temporary suspension of vehicle service will add around six miles to the journeys of motorists hoping to take their cars between the island and the peninsula.
The ferry shortens that trip to less than 1,000 feet.
Oneg ride are $1.25 for adults and 50 cents for children 5 to 11. For bicyclists, the fares rise to $1.50 for adults and 75 cents for children.

column1: San Diego County plane crash victims identified as two nurses and two pilots
column6:
SAN DIEGOï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thefour people killedwhen a medical transport jet crashed in an unincorporated area near the suburb of El Cajon this week were identified Wednesday by authorities, friends and professional organizations.
The San Diego County medical examinerï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s office identified two of the victims as Douglas James Grande, 42, and Julian Jorge Bugaj, 67. Both men were licensed pilots. Friends and colleagues said nurses Tina Ward and Laurie Gentz were the passengers.
For the record:
4:21 p.m. Dec. 30, 2021A previous version of this story said pilot Douglas James Grande was 45 years old. He was 42.
The four were on a Learjet 35 thatcrashed and exploded on a residential streetin the Bostonia neighborhood about 1.5 miles from Gillespie Field, killing everyone on board.
Under cold and dark skies Wednesday, several people ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ presumably friends and family ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ were allowed behind the yellow tape that surrounded the crash site. They left without talking to reporters. Moments later, authoritiepened the scene.
Left behind was a makeshift memorial of bright flowers and messages. Among them was a family photo ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Grande with a woman and two girls ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ with messages scrawled on the white frame. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I love you so much dad. I miss you,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ one read. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You are my everything,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ read another.
Grandeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s LinkedIn page states that he was a captain with Aeromedevac Air Ambulance and had been with the medical transport company since May 2019, also working as a first officer.
Aeromedevac posted onits Facebook pageWednesday images of two black ribbons and the words ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½With a heavy heart we mourn the lives of our friends and our family.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ It later added a post confirming ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½the devastating loss of our colleagues.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The loss of our friends has left us an indescribable void. To both us and their families they are unsung heroes, dedicating their lives caring for others in need throughout our community,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the statement said, in part.
Aalifornia
Two crew members and two passengers were killed in the El Cajon crash Monday evening.
Ward, one of the flight nurses, was the wife of recently retired Oceanside Deputy Fire Chief Joe Ward, according to anInstagram postTuesday from the union that represents Oceanside Fire Department members.
Acting Oceanside Fire Chief David Parsons sent a message to other fire chiefs in the region confirming the death and saying that the ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½greater Oceanside Fire Department family has experienced a terrible loss.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Tina was well known within the department and words canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t convey the hurt and loss the family and many of us feel,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Parsons wrote. He said the Ward family was surrounded by support and had asked for privacy.
Wardï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Facebook page said she had joined Aeromedevac Air Ambulance as a flight nurse in August and had worked as an emergency room nurse at Palomar Pomerado Health in northern San Diego County. Her page also includes several pictures of her with her husbannt posted a day before the deadly crash.
Gentz was identified in a Facebook post by theInternational Assn. of EMTs and Paramedics, which said Gentz was the president of a local chapter.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½President Gentz will be greatly missed by all who knew her and all who benefit from her selfless contributions to organized labor in the Greater San Diego area,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the post reads.
On her Facebook page, Gentz had noted that she started with Aeromedevac in February and previously had worked with another air ambulance company.
Gentz also worked with American Medical Response, which provides medical transport services such as ambulances. The company declined to offer a full statement out of respect for Aeromedevac but said it was ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½grieving along with their team, and we offer our deepest condolences to the organization and the families, friends and colleagues of those involved.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The plane had taken off from Orange Countyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s John Wayne Airport less than 20 minutes before crashing about 7:15 p.m.Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board are investigating the incident and have not said what led to the crash.
On Tuesday, the NTSB said the plane had been on an instrument approach to Runway 17 at Gillespie Field. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½As the airplane neared the airport environment, the pilot requested a change to a visual approach to Runway 27R,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ an agency spokesperson said.
It was unclear why the runway change was made, but one aviation expert said the pilot may have wanted to use a longer runway because of rain and mist in the region that night.
Max Trescott, a flight instructor who specializes in aviation safety, said it appeared the pilottried to perform a difficult landing maneuverat an unusually low altitude shortly before the crash.
In the hours before Monday nightï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s fatal crash, the jet had flown to Arizona and Orange County before returning to El Cajon.
According to the Flight Aware website, the plane left Gillespie Field just before 2 p.m., landing at Lake Havasu Cityï¿½ï¿½5 minutes later.
The plane took off about 90 minutes after that and arrived at John Wayne Airport just after 4:45 p.m.
The plane left John Wayne at 6:56 p.m. and crashed shortly before 7:15 p.m. while on approach to Gillespie.
