column1: 7 enchanting places go forest bathing in Southern California
column6:
Forest bathing, orshinrin-yoku, emerged in Japan in the 1980s as a form of nature therapy. How it works: You get out into a natural setting, mindfully observe your surroundings, and engage your senses. Basically, youslow down. A number ofresearch studiesrecognize the practice as a way to ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½reduce stress, improve mood andeven boost the immune system.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Times contributor Sara Cagleattended a forest bathing classat the L.A. County Arboretum and Botanic Garden (which is currently holdingguided full moon forest bathsthroughout the summer) and documented the experience.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½One person noticed the chirping of songbirds,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Cagle writes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Another stared at the vibrant shades of green. One woman said she became so relaxed, she felt like she was shedding her first skin.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Get The Wild newsletter.
The essential weekly guide to enjoying the outdoors in Southern California. Insider tips on the best of our beaches, trails, parks, deserts, forests and mountains.
You may occasionally rLos Angeles Times.
Although guided classes are wonderful, forest bathing can be done in any natural setting, either with a group or alone. How should you go about it? There are no rules ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ simply turn off your devices and wander. Here are my seven favorite forest bathing spots in Southern California ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ with an optional hike to go with them.
1. Carbon Canyon Regional Park, Brea.Go for maximum shade for your summer forest bath under the redwoods via a2-mile loop in Orange County. Breaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Carbon Canyon Regional Park is home to the largest grove of coastal redwoods in Southern California (241Sequoia sempervirensspecimens, to be exact), the tallest here being nearly 100 feet. Planted in the 1970s for a local bank promotion, the dense forest provides a 10-plus-degree temperature drop ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ perfect for  combating the summer heat and providing a magical space for your sensory experience.
Trailhead:Carbon Canyon Nature TrailAddress:4442 Carbon Canyon Road, BreaDistance:2-mile loopElevation:100lots ($3 weekdays, $5 weekends)
2. Wildwood Canyon State Park, Yucaipa.Coast live oaks might just be the arboreal mascot of Southern California. There are plenty of local spots to find varieties (certainly in our popular green-space trifecta of the Santa Monica Mountains, Griffith Park and Angeles National Forest), but opt for a less-traveled forest by way of a 2.25-mile stroll through Yucaipaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Wildwood Canyon State Park. It may not surprise you to find fairy-tale-like groves of oak canopies along the Oak Tree Loop Trail, but a meditative meander in this forest is a one-of-a-kind bath.
Trailhead:Oak Tree LoopAddress:12241 Canyon Drive, YucaipaDistance:2.25-mile loopElevation:400 feetParking:dirt lot
3. Cooper Canyon Falls, Angeles National Forest.Enjoy a serene waterfall via a 3-mile out-and-back reflective romp on the Burkhart Trail deep in the San Gabriels. Starting fromBuckhorn Campground(which is a great spot to pitch a tent among the trees), the path parallels a quaint stream. And there are trees of trees. Moss-covered cedars, towering Jeffrey pines and iconic Douglas firs. Destinations are optional in forest bathing, but a good turnaround point is the eponymous cascade ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ although Cooper Canyon falls flow best after a rain, even a tranquil trickle adds an extra element of Zen to your trek.
Trailhead:Burkhart TrailAddress:Buckhorn Campground, PearblossomDistance:3-mile out-and-backElevation:750 feetParking:paved lot (Adventure Pass required)
4. Heaps Peak Arboretum, San Bernardino National Forest.The acreage is small but the restorative rewards are big on a 1-mile loop trail that features the Ann Henck Stewart Memorial Sequoia Grove, a SoCal rarity planted in the 1930s. Other trees to bathe under: Jeffrey pines, sugar pines, white fir, black oak, incense cedars and Coulter pines, which have the largest cones in the world (look for the educational display case for up-close viewing). Since Heaps Peak Arboretum is perched at 6,000 feet,check road conditionsbefore visiting.
Trailhead:Sequoia Traiss:29358 Rim of the World Highway #18, SkyforestDistance:1-mile loopElevation:100 feetParking:paved lot (Adventure Pass required)
5. Escondido Falls, Malibu.Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s no shortage of beautiful bark in the Malibu portion of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. You canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t go wrong with any hike, but I like Escondido Falls for its quick access off PCH and an interesting element that might normally spurn forest bathers. The 3.75-mile out-and-back trek actually starts via a paved two-thirds-mile ascent through extravagant beach-view residences (after all, Escondido does mean ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½hiddenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½). But you wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t only be bathing in mansions. Once you reach the canyon trail, youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll find sycamores, willows and oaks following a gentle stream. Your forest bathing terminus is a woodland grotto with 50-foot falls (please protect the habitat and donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t climb to the second tier). If all this makes you crave a rejuvenating swim, hop  PCH to a nearby beach.
Trailhead:Wind0 Winding Way, MalibuDistance:3.75-mile out-and-backElevation:550 feetParking:Paved lot ($12) or street parking (free along PCH)
6. Elysian Park.Donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t dismiss the eucalyptus trees. Though these fast-growing, drought-tolerant gum trees are often considered an arboreal controversy in California, their grand and aromatic presence can provide a welcoming forest bath (think aromatherapy). In my humble opinion, Will Rogers State Historic Park has the most impressive grove of the flourishing non-natives, but opt for a forest bath in the heart of the urban jungle at our cityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s oldest green space. The 2.5-mileWest Loophas eucalyptus but also towering palms, the hidden succulent treasures of Marian Harlow Memorial Grove and the Elysian Park Arboretum. Once filled with exotic trees, it is now an expansive picnic space, but look for interpretive signs detailing unique specimens like the naked coral tree.
Trailhead:West Loop TrailAddress:1025 Elysian Park Drive, Los AngelesDistance:2.5-mile loopElevation:2ng:street parking
7. Point Fermin Park, San Pedro.Though I may stretch the term ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½forestï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ here, this coastal green-space gem has one of the most impressive arboreal collections in any city park. For a fig focus, try a beginnerï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s bathing course at San Pedroï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Point Fermin Park, which has nearly 20 absolutely massive Moreton Bay figs, all of which are perfect for a shaded picnic. For an urban stroll, consider a 2.5-mile park-to-park walk that features the giant banyans, panoramic coastal views along seaside cliffs, peregrine falcons and a bit of history (look for the nearby sunken city and the Korean Friendship Bell). Plus, neighboring Royal Palms beach features perhaps the best beachside palm grove in L.A.
Trailhead:Point Fermin ParkAddress:807 W. Paseo Del Mar, San PedroDistance:2.5-mile out-and-backElevation:100 feetParking:paved lot or street parking
Local gardens are also some of the most satisfying venues for your next forest bathing journey ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ think the aforementionentington Library,Descanso Gardens,South Coast Botanic Gardenor theCalifornia Botanic Garden, all of which have an admission fee. Wherever you bathe, just remember to breathe and take in the natural beauty surrounding you.
1. Wish upon some stars (while learning about them too) at the Night Sky Festival in the Santa Monica Mountains.Enjoy some ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½nocturnal entertainmentï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (as Carl Sagan referred to stargazing) at National Park Serviceï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sNight Sky Festivalon Saturday from 7 to 10 p.m. at Paramount Ranch. As part of their Park After Dark Festival Series, rangers and telescopes will be on site to help you discover the mysteries of our Milky Way galaxy (or, for your young ones, become a night sky junior ranger). Bring a flashlight, warm layers and your curiosity.
2. Enjoy the ride at Bike Day at L.A. State Historic Park.On Sunday, from 9 a.m. to noon, meet up with like-minded folks with different spokes atBike Dayand learn about CiBiC, the UCLA-led Civic Bicycle Commuting project that encourages.People for Mobility Justicewill also be there to help riders of all ages  learn skills and safety on a bike course, as well as how to commute in DTLA. There will be snacks, art workshops and bicycle raffles.
3. Explore a secret canyon with a guide in Rancho Palos Verdes.The 51-acre oasis that is George F. Canyon Nature Preserve is the epitome of a hidden gem ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ you immediately feel whisked away from the surrounding suburbia while taking in an incredible variety of native shrub land and woodland flora. See it all on Saturday at 9 a.m. witha guided hike,which begins at the nature center. If you want more mileage and more hidden gems, head to the 28.5-acreLinden H. Chandler Preservefor another charming trail.
4. Climb to coastal views with Just Trek in Temescal Canyon.The 4.6-mile workout to Skull Rock in Pacific Palisadesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Temescal Gateway Park gains 1,100 feet and rewards with epic coastal panoramas. Just Trekï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s founder, Justin ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Justrocï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Rimon,will be leading the event,mmunity with like-minded folks, improve your overall physical fitness and soak in the stellar vistas together. Plan to arrive at the trailhead on Saturday at 8:30 a.m.Tickets are $5.
5. Catch an outdoor performance at the Griffith Park Shakespeare Festival.The Independent Shakespeare Company is back with its classicGriffith Park plays Wednesday through Sunday at 7 p.m.This weekend marks the final performances of the rarely performed comedy ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The Knight of the Burning Pestle,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ written by a friend of Shakespeareï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s. Next month marks the return of a Bard classic, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Macbeth,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ which will feel even eerier at Griffithï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Old Zoo venue. Registration is free but limited, and seating is first-come, first-served. Looking for more Griffith Park entertainment? Check out the newï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Signs of Lifeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ planetarium show, which aims to ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ uncover what it took to put life in the universe.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
6. Do a downward dog with your dog under the Hollywood Sign.Join PetSwapuided yoga with your furry friendat the beautiful Lake Hollywood Park. Bringing Fido is optional, but there will be tons of canines to breathe and bark with at the session, which also has guided music and both doggy and human refreshments.
7. Attend a summer festival to celebrate our communities.Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the season for outdoor entertainment and we are fortunate to live in a city that loves fun under the sun. Check out theKCRW Summer Nights seriesat downtownï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Grand Park for some seriously cool live music this Saturday from 6 to 10 p.m. (consider taking an urban art walk beforehand) or Redondo Beachï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sSummer Concert Series on the Pier.
Our daily news podcast
If youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re a fan of this newsletter, youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll love our daily podcast ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The Times,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ hosted every weekday by columnist Gustavo Arellano, along with reporters from across our newsroom. Go beyond the headlines. Download and listenon our App, subscribeon Apple Podcastsand followon Spotify.
Gabrielino Trail to Brownmmertime shade-friendly hike in the Angeles National Forest, youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re likely to stumble across the popular trek throughBear Canyon to Switzer Falls. And for good reason! But this weekend, share the shade with fewer folks via the highly accessible Gabrielino Trail to Brown Mountain Dam. Featured in The Timesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½list of top 10 shaded hikes, itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a 10-mile out-and-back adventure (roughly 900 feet of gain) from Hahamongna Watershed Natural Park (disc golf, anyone?) to the 1943 dam, which was the first project of the U.S. Forest Service Los Angeles River Watershed program. The relatively flat trail follows a quaint stream and meanders under the protection of oaks, pines, firs and walnut trees. The 81-foot falls still have water trickling down in the summer, perfect for a refreshing mid-hike cool-down and a picnic lunch. If you want a shorter (but arguably more challenging) workout, opt for a technical2.25-mile trip that switchbacks into the canyon.
In case you havenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t noticed, itï¿½ï¿½wnrveled at the incredible efforts of firefighters to save Yosemiteï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Mariposa Grove of sequoias from theWashburn fire. However, since then, California has already experienced its largest burn of the season; the Oak fire, which started Friday in the Sierra Nevada foothills west of Yosemite National Park, has forced thousands to evacuate. Now, California Gavin Newsom has officiallydeclared a state of emergencyfor Mariposa County. With infernos like these and the huge current and future impacts of climate change, Times writer Alex Wigglesworth shares a grim reality: with fires as severe as these, some forestsmight vanish forever. Read Times reporterMadalyn Amatoï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s tips for wildfire preparationand keep an eye on our2022 wildfire map.
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s official: Monarchs are endangered. Last week, the International Union for the Conservation of Naturemoved the beloved butterflies to the ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½red listï¿½ï¿½ï¿½with its newfound threatened species classification. The royal pollinators are known for theigration from Mexico to Canada and back (upwards of 3,000 miles!), the longest of any insects.Despite recent optimism, the rate of decline has surged (experts estimate ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½between 22% and 72% over 10 years, depending on the measurement methodï¿½ï¿½ï¿½), prompting environmental groups to push for protection under the Endangered Species Act. And letï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s hope this comes soon ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ after all, their famous metamorphosis is an iconic symbol for change.
What can we do to help? Last year, Times writer Jeanette Marantos documentedsix ways to help the magical migrator, the most important being plantingnativemilkweed. We can also simplyobserve the winged wonders. Though not as abundant as during thefall-winter migratory period(October to February), butterfly-watchers can help gather data in ongoing conservation efforts this summer with theInternational Monarch Monitoring Blitzhappening July 29 through Aug. 7.
The best way to hike the Appalachian Trail this summer is in your backyard. With the most famous hecomingincreasingly crowded, why not delay the bucket list adventure and walk the nearly 2,200 miles on your own terms, time and terrain? With theWalk the Distance app, hikers can track their miles as they virtually hike the AT, progressing along a map (you can also do the PCT!). Make it to Georgiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Blood Mountain, the highest point on the journey, after a morning neighborhood stroll, or summit Mt. Katahdin, the trailï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s north terminus, after bagging a peak in our resident San Gabriels. Doing the real thing can be a truly life-changing experience (as Times writer Ben Poston noted inhis beautiful, inspiring account), but sometimes we all need a little motivation to discover and appreciate our local trails and work toward those fitness goals we set last year.
Times writer Melissa Hernandez recently reported thata mountain lion was struck and killedalong the 101 Freeway, thesecond big cat to suffer a traffic tragedyin the Santa Monica Mountains in the last month. The recently deceased young couga a 2-year-old male and one of many who regularly attempt to cross the busy freeway. In an effort to provide cougars and other animals safe passage, the Wallis Annenberg Wildlife Crossingbroke ground in April. The bridge is expected to be completed in 2025, but thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s more we can do. In fact, California senators will considerAB-2344next month; the Safe Roads and Wildlife Protection Act would require ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Caltrans to identify potential wildlife barriers on all future transportation projects and implement at least 10 projects that improve wildlife crossings.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ This would be a huge victory ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ after all, asThe Times Editorial Board noted: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Mountain lions may top the food chain in the wild, but on a road, the car is the apex predator.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ To join the fight for protection, consider educating yourself with resources from theNational Park Service(and a visit to theSanta Monica Mountains National Recreation Area) or volunteering with local groups likeSave L.A. Cougarsand theCougaWeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll help you find the best places to hike, bike and run, as well as the perfect silent spots for meditation and yoga.

Matt Pawlik writes about all things outdoors in Southern California. He took over The Wild newsletter for The Times from July to September 2022. When he needs to escape L.A., you can find the mattitude camping under the stars in Joshua tree or backpacking through the Sierras.

column1: Oak fire near Yosemite grows to 19,000 acres, but firefighters are gaining upper hand
column6:
Slow growth continued onthe Oak firenear Yosemite National Park on Thursday, with the blaze reaching 19,191 acres by nightfall as firefighters appeared to be gaining an upper hand.
The fire grew by a little more than 400 acres from the day before, officials said Thursday. It was the smallest daily growth so far for the Oak fire, which has been burning for six days, said California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection information officer David Clark.
Containment on the blaze rose to 42%, Cal Fire officials said Thursday night.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Today was hotter and drier as expected, but cloud cover in the area prevented further drying and heating of fuels,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Cal Fire said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Monsoonal moisture is expected to return early next week, which should lower temperature and raise humidity levels.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The slowdown is a stark contrast to the fireï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s first 24 hours, which saw explosive growth and extreme conditions turn the wildfire intoCaliforniaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s largest of the season so far.
Most of thsday to Thursday occurred on the northeastern perimeter of the fire.
California
As the sun rose over the Sierra Nevada foothills, it appeared burnt orange through hazy skies in Mariposa County.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s growing in a very casual and gradual way,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Clark said of the fire. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We do have crews in place to mitigate any hot spots. Overall, we are expecting to see containment of the fire to increase and behaviors to stay the same.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A total of 3,758 personnel are battling the fire, which has destroyed 135 structures and damaged 10 others, officials said. Nearly 700 structures remain threatened.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We have a very inaccessible, steep, rocky terrain that the fire is growing in, and weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re having helicopters fly in,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Clark said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We have to get crews there.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Anair quality advisoryhas been extended through Thursday for communities in the San Francisco Bay Area. Winds are expected to continue pushing smoke from the fire site into the Bay Area, accordingke is expected to remain aloft but may cause hazy skies across the Bay. Good to moderate air quality is forecast through the week,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the air district said.
California
As authorities began lifting evacuation orders, some Oak fire residents were learning whether they had homes to return to.
Theair quality indexin Mariposa County remained moderate Thursday evening. Elderly people and those with health issues are advised to stay indoors.
The Oak fire began Friday afternoon near Midpines, marking the start of the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s peak wildfire season. The fire quickly exploded in size, causing Gov. Gavin Newsom todeclare a state of emergencyfor Mariposa County on Saturday.
A community meeting was scheduled for 7 p.m. Thursday at Mariposa County High School. Mariposa Elementary School is serving as a Red Cross evacuation center.

column1: August is coming. Prepare for climate calamity
column6:
This is the July 28, 2022, edition of Boiling Point, a weekly newsletter about climate change and the environment in California and the American West.Sign up hereto get it in your inbox.
Lake Siskiyou is beautiful this time of year.
About 200 miles north of Sacramento, the artificial reservoir ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ formed by a dam on the Sacramento River ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ is ringed by quiet beaches that offer a cool respite from triple-digit heat. The views of Mt. Shasta are spectacular. When I visited last week, I saw double-crested cormorants, ospreys and great blue herons soaring over the water and ducklings swimming with their mother.
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a great spot to take a few days off from work. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s also not immune to the climate challenges confronting California and the American West as we enter August ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a crucial month for water supplies, wildfires, extreme heat and possible power shortages.
Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m not trying to be a downer. As Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve writtenagainandagain, thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a lot that can be done told offer a nasty reminder of why climate action is so badly needed.
Letï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s start with the electric grid.It was two years ago this August that parts of the Golden State sufferedrolling blackoutsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and we could be in store for more. Officials havewarnedof ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½a high degree of vulnerabilityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ this summer as rising temperatures drive up air conditioning demand. The risk is especially bad on August and September evenings, after solar panels stop generating.
I asked Neil Millar, a vice president at the California Independent System Operator, about the odds of additional power shortfalls this summer. Not surprisingly, he wasnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t thrilled about the question, telling me it was like asking ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½how bad bad luck could get.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve been in unprecedented times,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.
Overall, Millar was optimistic.He said the state has addedthousands of megawatts of batteriesthat can bank solar power for after dark, and has taken steps to secure other energy supplies a pinch, even as they fuel the global warming thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s gotten us into this mess. A bunch of solar-plus-storage projects that officials feared would be delayed by supply-chain slowdowns or other economic disruptions ended up plugging into the grid on schedule.
But the Independent System Operator canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t guarantee the lights will stay on, especially if the weather gets crazy.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re as well positioned as we could have hoped to be,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Millar said.
This isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t just a California concern. Across the country, the risk of blackouts is frighteningly high as rising temperatures strain electric grids and coal and nuclear power plants shut down, as Alexander C. Kaufman reports in adetailed storyfor HuffPost.
Another part of the problem: Intense drought means thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s less water behind dams to spin turbines and generate hydropower. Just look at my colleague Myung J. Chunï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sdramatic photos of Shasta Lake, where water levels fell to 38% of capacity last week.
Californitave off a bigger electric-grid collapse. But shutting off anyoneï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s power during a heat wave is painful, and potentially lethal. As The Timeshas reported, extreme heat kills more Californians than officials have acknowledged, and global warming is making things worse ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ especially for people who canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t afford air conditioning.
Government agencies are trying to protect the most vulnerable. The Biden administration this week launchedheat.govto share tips on keeping cool and other information to help local officials deal with heat, as Lisa Friedmanreportsfor the New York Times. Closer to home, the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power is designing aprogramthat would help low-income and elderly customers ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and people who depend on electricity for medical equipment ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ purchase air conditioning units at a low cost.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Lives are at stake. Los Angeles residentsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ health is at stake,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ DWP board President Cynthia McClain-Hill said at Tuesdayï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s board . It means members of our families, and our neighbors.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
None of those steps will eliminate the risks of heat illness or death. But they can definitely help ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ especially with Northern California in the grips of ascorching heat wave, and with the hottest part of the yearyet to comefor coastal Southern California.
Compared with extreme heat ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ which we can expect to get worse just about every year ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ wildfire is more of a wild card.So far in 2022, just 53,000 acres have burned in California ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ far below thefive-year averageof 415,000 acres by this point in July.
But weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re now entering one of the most dangerous times of year for fire activity, as heat dries out the already parched landscape. The Oak fire has quickly become the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½slargest blazeof 2022 since igniting Friday, burningmore than 18,000 acresnear Yosemite National Park and destroying 25 homes. Thousands of people have been forced to evacuate, with one resident of the Sierra Nevada foothills town o fire blew up, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½it looked like Godzilla over my house.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Eighteen thousand acres isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t much compared with therecord-breaking million acresconsumed by 2020ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s August Complex fire ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ or last yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sDixie fire, which chewed through nearly as much ground. But the Oak fire would have been considered a big one just a few decades ago, according to UC Merced climatologist John Abatzoglou. And it could be a prelude to the rest of the year.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a lot more of the fire season yet to go, and things are really crispy out there,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Abatzoglou said.
When I asked Abatzoglou for his top three wildfire solutions, two of his answers involved more fire: settingï¿½ï¿½ï¿½prescribed burnsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½to clear out vegetation in forests that have grown much too dense after a century of overly aggressive fire suppression, and allowing blazes in remote areas far from homes to burn themselves out ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a strategy known as ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½managed fire.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½d ao clear excess vegetation from around their properties.
What about reducing climate pollution? It needs to happen, Abatzoglou said, but itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not an immediate fire solution.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Even though Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m a climate person, I know weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re not going to slow this down in the next 20 years too much,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.
As if wildfires werenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t scary enough on their own, they can also exacerbate power-grid problems. Utility companies sometimesshut off electricityduring high winds to stop their electric lines from sparking fires. Last summer, smoke from the Bootleg fire in southern Oregonknocked out several linesthat bring power to California, nearly leading to rolling blackouts here.
Then thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the drought situation.If you havenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t heard,itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s badï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and August could bring more unwelcome news.
In the next few weeks, the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation will issue its latest forecast for water levels at the American Westï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s two largest reservoirs: Lake Mead and Laks of acres of farmland, from Los Angeles to Phoenix to Salt Lake City. The August forecast typically determines whether California, Arizona, Nevada and Mexico will see their Colorado River water deliveries reduced, as they were following last Augustï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sfirst-ever shortage declaration.
Next monthï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s reservoir forecast will be grim ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ but thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s almost beside the point, says John Fleck, a Colorado River expert and writer in residence at the University of New Mexico School of Lawï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Utton Transboundary Resources Center. Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s because in mid-June, the Bureau of Reclamation gave the seven Colorado River states60 daysto develop a plan to reduce water use dramatically ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ by 2 million to 4 million acre-feet next year. If they donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t make it happen, the federal agency couldorder draconian cutbacks.
Everyone will need to use less water, Fleck told me. But he suggested it will be especially important for wealthy cities to find ways to compensate rural, agriculturrial Valleyfor cutting back.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Climate change is coming in and taking their water. But we need to help them,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Fleck said.
So far, there are no real public signs a robust plan will come together. The riverï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Upper Basin states ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ havedeclinedto promise anything substantial, saying the onus should be on the Lower Basin states, per Luke Runyon at KUNC. And itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s unclear if California and the other Lower Basin states are having much success in agreeing on cutbacks.
Fleck said the most ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½politically expedientï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ path forward ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ especially in Arizona, where water cuts aredeeply unpopularï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ might be to punt to the federal government. He thinks that would be an unfortunate outcome, embracing conflict over cooperation.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve got to own up and take responsibility for the fact that this is all of our faults as water users,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Fleck said.
Meanwhile, water levels continue to fall. Lake Me you, check out thesewild NASA satellite photosshowing how the desert reservoir has shrunk. Human remains were found on a Lake Mead beach this week as the water receded ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ thethird time thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s happened since May, my colleague Christian Martinez reports.
Just like with wildfire, slashing planet-warming emissions is not an immediate solution to the long-term drying trend in the American West.But without serious climate action, thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s also no way to avoid even worse catastrophe down the road.
Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s still possible the federal government will get its act together. Sen. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a Democrat who for months has blocked President Bidenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s climate proposals ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½abruptly announcedlate Wednesday heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½d struck a deal to support a sweeping bill focused on energy and climate, among other issues. The details were still coming into focus as of this writing, but hereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s anearly summaryfrom my colleague Jennifer Haberkorn, who writes that tclimate policies.
In California, Gov. Gavin Newsom is trying to step up on climate, even as hesupportsthe short-term use of fossil fuels to bolster power supplies. He sent aletterto state regulators last week asking them to plan for a gargantuan20 gigawattsof offshore wind power by 2045, and setting a target of 7 million ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½climate-ready and climate-friendly homesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ by 2035. That could mean homes equipped withelectric heat pumpsinstead of polluting gas furnaces, and retrofitted to keep people cool during heat waves.
Newsom also asked state agencies to plan for a clean energy transition that includes no new natural gas plants ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a big win for climate activists.The California Air Resources Board has recentlyprojecteda need for 10 gigawatts of new gas plants to help keep the lights on when solar panels and wind turbines arenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t generating, and to support electric-vehicle charging.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This isnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t revolution. This should be the expectation,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Alexandra Nagy, Cali Sunstone Strategies, which works closely with environmental groups and has pushed Newsom to take bolder action on climate.
It was hard for me not to think about this stuff last week, even as I relaxed on the shore of Lake Siskiyou.Had drought reduced hydropower production at Box Canyon Dam, which I glimpsed while hiking around the reservoir? How much cooler would it be if the planet hadnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t already warmed up so much? Would I see more birds? Would there bemore snowpack on Mt. Shasta?
I donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have good answers to those questions. I do recommend the occasional vacation, though. We all deserve a break.
Hereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s what else is happening around the West:
California is making plans to rely on carbon capture ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ at least a little bit ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ to meet its climate goals.But environmental critics say the technology would extend the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s reliance on fossil fuels andcontinue a harmful legacy of pollutionin low-income neighborhoods, my colleague Tony Briscoe writes. The stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½slize its all-important climate ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½scoping planï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ this fall, so look out for more news on this front. In another key political development, Gov. Gavin Newsom is opposing a Lyft-backed ballot measure that would tax multimillionaires and put the money toward electric car rebates and wildfire prevention, calling Proposition 30 ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½a special interest carve-out.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Details herefrom the Sacramento Beeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Owen Tucker-Smith.
It took three years, but the Newsom administration has new details on a proposed delta tunnel to move Sacramento River water to Southern California and the San Joaquin Valley.The latest iteration of this massive infrastructure project ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ first proposed many decades ago ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ would skirt under the eastern edge of the ecologically fragile estuary where the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers meet, rather than under the deltaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s heart, Dale Kasler and Ryan Sabalowreport for the Sacramento Bee. But the project still has many critics, and itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s unclen wouldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t start until 2028.
Reuters published a powerful investigation of the radioactive contamination from Santa Susana Field Lab just outside L.A. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and Boeingï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s use of a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½conservation easement,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ which critics see as an increasingly common tool for companies to limit their toxic waste cleanup responsibility.Hereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the storyfrom reporters Jaimi Dowdell and Andrea Januta. See alsothis Arizona Republic pieceby Zayna Syed about the lack of funding for cleaning up hundreds of abandoned uranium mines on the Navajo Nation, andthis High Country News pieceby Jonathan Thompson about oil companies evading cleanup obligations in New Mexico.
One of Mexicoï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wealthiest cities has so little water that many residents ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ especially the poor ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ get nothing when they turn on their taps.Whatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s happening in Monterrey is awarning for the Western U.S., my colleague Kate Linthicum writes. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a warning at least some places are taking seriouslyý purifying wastewater and putting it right back into the tap ýýý and L.A. could bethe first city to actually do it, The Timesýýý Jaimie Ding reports. Las Vegas islimiting the sizeof new residential swimming pools, per Grace Da Rocha at the Las Vegas Sun. And many individuals continue to do their part ýýý including one Pasadena residentembracing ýýýhugelkulturýýýto reduce her water use, as Jeanette Marantos writes.
Could robots picking indoor crops keep food production humming even as rising temperatures, water shortages and chemical regulation slam traditional agriculture?Hereýýýs thefascinating storyby my colleague Sam Dean, focused on the California strawberry industry. I hadnýýýt realized 90% of the nationýýýs strawberries are grown along the California coast, which is pretty cool. In other agriculture news, ranchers say cattle grazing in the West is crucial for the health of the land ýýý but thereýýýsa lot of science showing otherwise, including serious climate damage. Thanks to Georgina Gustin at Inside Climate News for the story.
How did California go from paying hunters to destroy mountain lions to spending millions protecting them?The Timesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Patt Morrisontraced the history, from some ugly L.A. Times coverage a century ago, to the role of Ronald Reagan in reining in hunting, to the ballot measure that ultimately created funding to buy habitat for the majestic beasts. (Another mountain lion waskilled on the 101 Freewaylast week, marking four of them killed by cars in Southern California this year.) In other Western wildlife news, the International Union for Conservation of Nature has determined monarch butterflies are at risk of extinction ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ but the U.S. still hasnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t given the migrating insects endangered species protections.Details herefrom Christina Larson at the Associated Press.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We have set the precedent, and it is the pursuit of justice.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½For the first time ever, government has returned land that was wrongfully taken from a Black family ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½gue Rosanna Xiawrote about the heartfelt ceremonyin which the Bruce family took ownership of Bruceï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Beach. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Today, weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re sending a message to every government in this nation confronted with the same challenge: This work is no longer unprecedented,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ L.A. County Supervisor Janice Hahn said.
Nonprofit news outlet Floodlight and the Orlando Sentinel have several new entries in their eye-popping investigation into Florida Power & Light, a subsidiary of NextEra Energy, the nationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s largest power company.First, Floodlightï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Mario Alejandro Ariza and the Sentinelï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Annie Martin reported that operatives working for the Florida utilitygained control over a political news websiteand influenced coverage to try to benefit the company. Next, the journalistsrevealedthat NextEra consultant Matrix LLC ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ which has been described as ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½the closest thing Alabama politics has to a non-governmental secret agencyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ has worked on campaigns not on. (Floodlightï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Miranda Green also  co-wrote that story.)
A bill sailing through the California Legislature would task state officials with estimating the carbon emissions intensity of oil tanked in from overseas.At least one climate-friendly lawmaker supports the legislation. But itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s also backed by the oil industry, and environmental critics suspect the data would be used topromote in-state drilling, Aaron Cantu reports for Capital & Main.
Ford has signed a binding agreement to buy lithium for electric car batteries from the proposed Rhyolite Ridge mine in Nevada.Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s part of a growing effort by the U.S. auto industry tosource lithium domestically, from spots such as northern Nevada andCaliforniaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Salton Sea, Reutersï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Ernest Scheyder reports ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a priority for car companies in part due toforced-labor concernsat Chinese lithium mines. But the domestic lithium push faces a backlash from some conservationists. The Associated Pressï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Scott Sonner wrote aboutithium mining and geothermal energy projects in Nevada.
In related news, Kansas is getting the largest economic development project in its history ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a $4-billion Panasonic lithium-ion battery factory that will rival Teslaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Nevada Gigafactory in scale.Hereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the storyfrom Canary Mediaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Shel Evergreen.
Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s still no word on when the California Public Utilities Commission might propose new rooftop solar incentive rates, six months after Newsom basically rejected its previous proposal.That didnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t stop protesters from gathering at Sempra Energy headquarters tovoice their displeasurewith the company, whose San Diego Gas & Electric subsidiary has pushed for lower incentives, as the San Diego Union-Tribuneï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Rob Nikolewski reports. Stay tuned as I continue to track this story.
The writer Mike Davis is legendary for chronicling the story of Los Angeles, most notably in the 1990 book ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½City of Quartz.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s also known as a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½propther tome, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Ecology of Fear.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Now heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s dying of esophageal cancer ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and as much as he sees climate nightmares on the horizon, heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s also got ideas for how people can demand change. As hetold my colleague Sam Dean: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve forgotten the use of disciplined, aggressive but nonviolent civil disobedience. Take climate change. We should be sitting in at the headquarters of every oil company every day of the week. You could easily put together a national campaign. You have tons of people who are willing to get arrested, who are so up to do it.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll be back in your inbox next week. If you enjoyed this newsletter, please consider forwarding it to your friends and colleagues.

column1: The Jan. 6 hearings arenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t playing the way Democrats hope in one California swing di
column6:
CERES, Calif.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Even before the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 insurrection called a single witness, Amador Martinez had seen enough.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s on him,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said of former President Trump, who capped his efforts to overturn the 2020 electionby siccing an angry and vengeful mob on the Capitol. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½One hundred and ten percent.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Melody Douglas also made up her mind long beforethe first hearing was gaveled open in TVï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s prime time.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a sham,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said of the committee and its work. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s just an effort to make Trump look bad. Hopefully, heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s holding his head high.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol, as the panel is called, has offered a riveting account of apower-mad president and the crises his ego and insecurities foisted on the country.
Its public hearings, in eight installments, have drawn millions of viewers, offered a strong case for Tare, abuse of Secret Service agents ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the pathology of the president and his hissy fits.
Cassidy Hutchinsonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Jan. 6 hearing testimony underscores why Trump should never get near the White House again.
What the hearings have apparently failed to do, at least so far, is change a great many minds or alter the way voters seem to be approaching Novemberï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s midterm elections.
For Caitlyn Miller, the committeeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s findings merely reinforce what she believed all along, that Trump did nothing to stop the violence and will probably get away with his sordid behavior, along withRepublicans who aided and abetted his attempt at a coup.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s kind of annoying to listen and watch and read how sï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ everyone was,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Miller, 30, an office worker in Modesto, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½and then to think no oneï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s going to be held responsible.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Her focus this election is on other issues where, the Democrat believes, her vote could make a difference: climate change, abortiher personal freedoms, like same-sex marriage.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I donotwant to see Republicans in control,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Miller said emphatically, thrusting her arms out as though she could personally shove HouseGOP leader Kevin McCarthyaway from the speakership.
Nationwide, there are relatively few House races that are genuine toss-ups; perhaps three dozen or so.
One of them is here in the Central Valley, where Democrat Adam Gray and Republican John Duarte are vying to represent a newly created district sprawling south from the outskirts of the Bay Area.
The 13th Congressional District is mostly rural ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ two-lane highways, farm stands, feedlots, endless orchards ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ save for a slice of Modesto, its next-door neighbor, Ceres, and Turlock.
With the temperature topping 100 degrees this week and the sky mottled with smoke from yet another Yosemite wildfire, the doings of lawmakers in Washington seemed quite remote. In interviews across the district, voters talked about inflation, drought, homelessness, water, th and,especially, high gas prices.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½There are a lot of other things going on in the world,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Sharon D., a 50-year-old Trump voter and mental health clinician in Ceres, who called the investigation into the Jan. 6 violence and its roots a waste of time and money. (She asked not to use her last name, to avoid harassment.) ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Nobody cares anymore.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unless something dramatically changes afterthecommittee resumes its hearings in September, the insurrection probably wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t play much of a role in deciding who wins the open congressional seat.
Democrats praised Gray, a 44-year-old state assemblyman, for his work in Sacramento. Republicans said Duarte, a 55-year-old farmer who also helps run a family-owned nursery, is the perfect fit for this agriculture-dependent district.

Douglas, a 60-year-old Republican h best president weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve had in a long timeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and hopes he runs again in 2024.

The 55-year-old landscaping contractor, a Ceres Democrat, said he has closely followed the hearings and believes it was every citizenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s duty to do so.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We need people to take responsibility,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Martinez said of the assault on the Capitol and, more, democracy itself.
In a red-versus-blue world where some refuse to acknowledge even basic facts, itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s hardly surprising to find partisans dug into their positions, or ignoring evidence contrary to what they choose to believe.
But engagement and persuasion are just two measures of the committeeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s success, and hardly the most important.

allman paused to state her support for the Jan. 6 hearings.

column1: Wildfire roars past 4,200 acres, injures 2 and destroys at least 4 structures in San Diego County
column6:
SAN DIEGO COUNTYï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½A fast-moving wildfire in a rural part of east San Diego County grew to 4,243 acres by Wednesday night, ripping through bone-dry brush, injuring two people and destroying at least four buildings as the region baked under extreme heat.
Residents around Barrett Junction, a few miles northwest of Tecate, Mexico, scrambled to clear out after the fire erupted around 2:15 p.m. near Barrett Lake Road north of State Route 94.
By late Wednesday night, the blaze was 5% contained as it continued to rage, threatening the communities of Barrett, Potrero and Tecate, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.
Smoke could be seen for miles.
Apolonio Gilbert said he was working in the Barrett Lake Mobile Home Park when he saw flames and smoke in a nearby canyon. Gilbert, 62, jumped into his truck and drove around the park, honking and warning people to get out. He and his wife grabbed their three dogs and fled.
The fire burned through the park, but no homes there werlifornia

In the early hours of the fire, moderate winds fanned it eastward along the highway. Gusts reached 27 mph.
By 6 p.m., the fire jumped to the south side of State Route 94 and burned ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½very aggressivelyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ in the direction of Tecate and Potrero, Cal Fire San Diego Capt. Thomas Shoots said.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The winds have died down, but the fire remains very active,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said just before 8 p.m.
Shoots said there were ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½multiple close callsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ as residents rushed to evacuate. At least four structures, including at least one home, were destroyed, Shoots said.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We had multiple 911 calls from folks unable to evacuateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ because their homes were surrounded by the fire, Shoots said.

California

The blaze was reported around 2:15 p.m. near BarState Route 94, Shoots said. By 4:45 p.m. it had roared past 1,400 acres as it pushed northeast toward the community of Potrero.

ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It is what it is, you hope for the best,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ge of Barrett Lake Road as they fled.
Lopezï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wife went to an evacuation center at Jamul Casino, but Lopez stayed at a dirt lot on the corner down the road from the fire, hoping heï¿½ï¿½ï¿½d be able to get home earlier.

ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You could hardly breathe,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Galvï¿½ï¿½n said, his eyes still puffy and moist from inhaling the smoke a few hours earlier.
As neighbors who live along Barrett Lake Road ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ most of them from the Barrett Lake Mobile Home Park ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ gathered at the corner where their street meets State Route 94, a Cal Fire firefighter approached and told them it would be a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½day or twoï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ until theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½d be able to go back home.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not over, but weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re do over, but it has burned through, and there could be embers, but all the trailers were saved.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Crews attacked the flames from the air and from the ground. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve requested every wildland engine from Cal Fire in San Diego County,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Shoots said.

column1: Extreme heat wave pushing California power grid to limit, with rolling blackouts possible

Extreme heat is expected to grip the vast majority of California for at least six days, perhaps even longer.

ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We are anticipating this extreme heat to be a length and duration the likes of which we havenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t experienced in some time,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday in urging residents to conserve power.

column1: California heat waves are getting worse. Blame the vicious ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½heat d
column6:
The high-pressure system over most of California is expected to bring record-breaking temperatures, part of a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½self-perpetuatingï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ system that is becoming more extreme as climate change worsens.
The extreme temperatures that will bear down on California over the next week are the result of a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½heat dome,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a phenomenon that typically brings broiling conditions to the state as summer fades into fall. But climate change is worsening the domeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s effects and making it more lethal for people who cannot seek relief.
Experts are sounding alarms about what they say is likely to be the worst heat wave of the year so far.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve always had these systems, but not as frequently, not as intense and not as long-lasting,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Bill Patzert, a retired climatologist in the Los Angeles area.
California
Forecasters say the Antelope Valley could see temperatures as high as 113 degrees during the ongoing heat wave.
From San Diego to Sacramento, the National Weather Servi through Labor Day, cautioning about thehealth risksof sustained high temperatures. Experts say the heat wave will also increase the chance of wildfires and power outages and will exacerbate the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ongoing drought.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This is going to be a long-duration event,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said UCLA climate scientist Daniel Swain. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½And thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s sort of characteristic of heat domes ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s partly because they can sort of be self-persisting, self-reinforcing. Once they develop and become particularly extreme, they kind of become hard to dislodge.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Swain said ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½heat domeï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ is a colloquial term for ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½a particularly persistent and strong region of atmospheric high pressure during the warm months.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When the high-pressure system moves into an area under certain conditions, it traps heat, similar to an insulated dome. This is what will bring extreme temperatures this week across California and Nevada.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½When youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re inside of a high-pressosphere, as opposed to upward motion ... and that suppresses clouds,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Swain said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It results in clear skies, so you get more solar radiation, more warming of the surface.
California needs to start treating extreme heat like the public health hazard it is.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½But beyond that ... you get additional warming, because that downward motion itself results in compressional heating.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
He called those simultaneous effects the ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½vicious-cycle feedbacksï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ of the heat dome: the heat dries out the soil, which eliminates atmospheric moisture, which allows the sun to more easily heat the Earthï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s surface and so on.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½You can kind of see how that becomes self-perpetuating,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Swain said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½And thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s what weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re going to see this week into next week over California and Nevada. Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re going to see this persistent high-pressure system ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ this is a pretty extreme heat dome ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s going to accumulate more and morekend, weather forecasters predict temperatures could reach as high as 115 degrees in some parts of Southern California.
Heat waves are becomingmore deadly and more common across the Golden State. Arecent study analyzing data from 1950 to 2020found that heat waves in Southern California were ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½starting earlier and ending later in the year for urban regions,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a trend that is ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½linked to human-induced climate change.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Glynn Hulley, a research scientist at NASAï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Jet Propulsion Laboratory who led that study, said his team found that heat waves have become ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½more frequent, intense and longer-lasting.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ He said this weekï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s heat wave  fits into the ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½more intenseï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ category, with record-breaking temperatures expected.

column1: LAPD searching for driver who ran over injured scooter rider with van, then drove off
column6:
Los Angeles police are searching for the driver of a van that ran over an injured scooter rider Saturday in Boyle Heights and did not stop.
The department is offering $25,000 for information leading to the driverï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s identification, arrest and conviction or settlement with the victim.
Just before 9 p.m. on Fickett Street, the Los Angeles Police Department said in a release, Luis Lopez was riding a scooter when he fell and was knocked unconscious.
Insurveillance footage released by the LAPD, Lopez is seen lying in the roadway, barely moving, for several seconds before a white Ford Econoline van comes into view.
The van drives over Lopez, dragging him down the street before he is dislodged from under the vehicle. Police said Lopez was dragged about 25 feet.
The van can be seen continuing to drive down the street and out of sight.
Lopez was taken to a hospital with severe injuries; he was stable and expected to recover as of Tuesday.
The LAPD released photos and a video of Lopez in his hospital bed with won his face, right arm and legs.

column1: International travel resurgent at LAX, with nearly 100% year-over-year increase in passengers
column6:
Los Angeles International Airport saw 1.8 million international travelers last month, nearly double the number from July 2021, airport officials said Monday.
The year-over-year increase is a sign of continued recovery for the travel industry, but numbers still have yet to reach pre-pandemic levels; in July 2019, more than 2.5 million international passengers flew through LAX.
Between January and July, the airport saw 8.7 million international passengers, up more than 141% from the same period last year.
Overall traffic at LAX ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ both international and domestic ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ is up 57% from last year.
Housing & Homelessness
Last monthï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s decline shows a market that is cooling off, and the rest of the U.S. could soon see similar relief, according to a Realtor.com analysis.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The strong rebound in international travel that we have seen during the peak summer months is very encouraging and adding to our overall growth in passenger numbers this season,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Justin Erbacci, chief executive of Lo in a news release.
The numbers of flights available to Mexico and Canada have rebounded to near pre-pandemic figures, and flights to the Middle East have exceeded levels last seen in 2019.
But the numbers of flights to and from Europe and Asia continue to lag behind pre-pandemic availability, with travel to Asia from LAX still less than half of what it was before the pandemic.
In July 2019, 2,521 flights and more than 775,319 seats were available from LAX to Asia, representing the largest international destination for the airport. Fewer than 1,140 Asia-bound flights and just under 324,000 seats were available last month.

column1: Newsom must do more to protect Californians from climate change and wildfire
column6:
Good morning, and welcome to the Essential Californianewsletter. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sFriday, Sept. 30, and Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½m Anita Chabria, The Timesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ California columnist.
This week, my colleague Erika D. Smith and I published a four-part series that asks an unpopular but crucial question:Should California rebuild everyvulnerable town burned by wildfire?
Our natural instinct is to offer aid to our fellow citizens in need ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ be it from fire, flood or other natural disasters such as the hurricane that devastated Florida this week.
But Erika and I spent months talking to climate scientists, fire officials, elected officials,residents who have been burned out of multiple homesand those who are in the process of rebuilding from the ashes of tragedy. What we found is a hard truth ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the combination of climate change and cost means that rebuilding, in many cases, is a foolï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s errand.
The chance of fire striking again is not just a risk, but a near certainty, meaning we areputting people back in harmmatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s whyErika and I are making the case to call it quitson our unqualified commitment to restore every town struck by catastrophe. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not that we donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t care about these communities. We do. We also are tired of seeing heartbreak repeated, at an enormous cost.
In the tiny Northern California town of Greenville, which burned almost entirely in last yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Dixie fire, we discovered that, when all is said and done, it will probably cost about $1 billion  to rebuild a place where about 300 people plan on returning.
We are rooting for Greenville and the many wonderful people devoting themselves to bringing back a town they love, but we also see it asa call to action for Gov. Gavin Newsom.
California needs a comprehensive land-use plan that looks at where and how we rebuild through the lens ofscience, not sentiment. We have to decide if we will continue to allow new homes to be built in high-risk zones for fire, and if we do, how much responsibility we are collectively willing to takurn.
There are no easy answers, but our political leaders owe it to us to work on these painful uncertainties now.

Inside the incredibly shrinking Southern California starter home.As home prices have soared and higher mortgage interest rates have made everything less affordable, wish lists have become more and more wishful, and buyers have been forced to find something smaller and less practical. Coming into focus.Once thought to affect s for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or ADHD, have sharply increased among adult women. But women arenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t suddenly waking up with a neurological disorder. But that lifesaving treatment is expensive, especially for those without health insurance, and can leave people saddled with thousands of dollars of debt. Rep. Ami Bera (D-Elk Grove) introduced legislationster the treatment to uninsured people.NPR
Dancer Isadora Duncan died in an automobile accident 95 years ago this month.Duncan was trying out a new car on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France, when a gust of windblew a long scarf that she was wearingaround her neck over the side of the car. It became entangled in one of the wheels and dragged the dancer out of the machine into the roadway. Her neck was broken. A French chauffeur was teaching her to drive the new car, which was speeding along when the dancer met death.
Auto accidents seemed to play a significant role in Duncanï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s life. On several occasions she was injured, sometimes seriously, in them, and in 1913 her two children, Beatrice, 5, and Patrick, 3, were drowned in the Seine, near Paris, when their vehicle ran into the river.

column1: Former PG&E executives agree to $117-million settlement over California wildfires
column6:
Former executives with utility giant Pacific Gas & Electric have reached a $117-million settlement agreement in connection with the 2017 North Bay fires and the 2018 Camp fire, officials said.
The former officers and directors were sued by a victim trust that claimed the deadly fires were the direct result of the former executivesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ actions, and the trust announced on Thursday that the agreement was finalized in San Francisco County Superior Court.
A dozen fires that ripped through Northern California in October 2017 were sparked by downed power lines owned by PG&E, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.  The fires raged across Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wine country, including Napa, Sonoma, Humboldt, Butte and Mendocino counties, and killed 19 people.
A year later, the Camp fire was sparked in Butte County by faulty electrical equipment operated by PG&E, authorities said. The fire decimated several communities, including the town of Paradise. In total, 85 people died in the  it the deadliest blaze in the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s history, according to authorities.
PG&E filed for bankruptcy in 2019 after it announced a $13.5-billion settlement with fire victims and their families. The PG&E Fire Victim Trust was created after the agreement under the utility companyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Chapter 11 reorganization plan.
Last year, the trust sued 20 former PG&E officers and directors, claiming they were directly responsible for the fires because of their breach of fiduciary duties to act in the best interest of the utility company.
Investigators with the California Public Utilities Commission found that there were systematic problems with PG&Eï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s oversight of the nearly 100-year-old power line that sparked the Camp fire. PG&E took over the power line in 1930, according to a December 2019 report.
California
Pacific Gas & Electric on Friday announced a $13.5 billion settlement for a string of recent fires in Northern California that killed dozens, and destroyed thousands of homes and businesses.
PG&E84 counts of involuntary manslaughterin federal court.
The lawsuit filed by the trust sought to hold the former executives accountable for not properly maintaining vegetation around electrical equipment and for not installing power shutoff equipment at the time of the 2017 fire. The suit also argued that the utility company did not properly update 100-year-old equipment in connection with the Camp fire.
Under its bankruptcy plan, PG&E allowed the Fire Victim Trust to pursue any claims held by the utility company, including against its former directors and officers, which the company says it suffered in connection with the wildfires, the trust said in a news release.
The settlement was finalized in July and the utility company is expected to submitted its approval in court, said attorney Frank Pitre, who is lead counsel for the trust in this lawsuit. Pitre is also a member of the trustï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s oversight committee.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½These funds will be used to satisfy the vast majority of outstanding fire victim claimrtain federal agencies that assisted in battling the fires and providing assistance to victims,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Pitre said in a statement.
That funding will go to agencies such as the Federal Emergency Management Agency, state agencies and other groups that helped house fire victims, Pitre said, which the trust is required to pay as part of the bankruptcy plan.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½With the vast majority of this settlement with the federal agencies satisfied, the trust is close to being able to use all future net recoveries from assigned claims to benefit other fire victims,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Pitre said.
News of the settlement was met with skepticism by Santa Rosa resident Will Abrams, whose home was destroyed in the Tubbs fire in 2017. As one of the approximately 70,000 victims who were affected  by the wildfires from 2015 to 2018, Abrams wants to know how much money the Fire Victim Trust is spending to pay for legal fees and to represent their interests.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½One group that absolutely benefits from the suits are the attorneys. Theaid for litigating these cases,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Abrams told The Times. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½So if the federal agencies are getting the beneficiaries of this lawsuit and getting some monies out of this, how much of the attorneysï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ fees and other fees are coming out of the Fire Victim Trust, coming out of victimsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ pockets?ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Abrams has filed a motion in court for more transparency in the bankruptcy process and for the trust to disclose how much money is being spent.
Pitre  told The Times his firm is working on a contingency basis but did not disclose how much of the Fire Victim Trust is going to pay for attorney fees.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The goal was always to try and preserve as much of the $13.5 billion that was earmarked and that was satisfied for the fire victims,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Pitre said.
Abrams said the opaque nature of the bankruptcy proceedings has left him frustrated. Nearly five years after the Tubbs fire, Abrams has still not received any information about how much money he can expect.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Many victims are w to get paid,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Abrams said.
In a written statement, PG&E called the agreement ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½another step forward in PG&Eï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ongoing effort to resolve issues outstanding from before its bankruptcy and to move forward focused on our commitments to deliver safe, clean and reliable energy to our customers, and to continue the important work of reducing risk across our energy system.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s only when youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re closer to the sign that youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll see the illustration of a multi-limbed Joshua tree arcing against a bright blue sky, signaling that youï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve arrived at the sandy-colored headquarters of the Mojave Desert Land Trust.

The sale also includes a few salvage items found on land trust properties, such as an old rusted pickup be and a stack of weathered boards.
The land trustï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s demonstration garden is open from sunrise to sunset every day for people who want to know what these native shrubs and trees look like when theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re older. One of the land trustï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s main jobs is to purchase small parcels of private land within the desertï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s national park and preserves, and then convey those lands to the national parks for continued protection. But it also operates a nursery devoted primarily to restoration and preservation work, Dacey said, such as its seed bank with seeds from some 700 plant collections stored in three giant refrigerators, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½an insurance policy for the Mojave Desert.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

That nursery is closed to the public, but twice a year, in the spring and fall, the land trust provides plants for desert dwellers to buy for their yards, partly as a fundraiser but also to encourage plantings ind several sales for native plants in Southern California this month and next, since late fall and winter are the best time for planting most natives ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ but the land trustï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s sale is one of the very few devoted to plants adapted to desert life. It gets hot here (itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the desert, right?), but it also getsverycold, sometimes as low as 20 degrees, said Madena Asbell, the trustï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s director of plant conservation. These hardy plants have evolved to survive in both extremes.
Some native plants do well throughout the region, such as California buckwheat and the red-throated California fuchsia, but others are less familiar outside of the desert, such as cheesebush (Ambrosia salsola), burro bush or bur-sage (Ambrosia dumosa) and yellow-blooming creosote bush (Larrea tridentata) ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the Mojave Desertï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ubiquitous and foundational shrub that provides food and shelter to a number of species, including the desert tortoise. It also has a defining characteristic: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The smell after it rains?ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Asbell said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s the smell of creosote.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The land trust grows its plants from seeds collected on its desert lands, and creosote is slow-growing, so it wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have any of those plants to sell until next yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s fall sale, said Asbell, but this yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s sale features50 other species,including rush milkweed (Asclepias subulata) and desert milkweed (Asclepias erosa); desert willows (Chilopsis linearis)with their frilly vanilla-scented blooms; and the delightfully named hole-in-the-sand (Nicolettia occidentalis),a skeletal, bristly-looking plant with bright pink and yellow flowers.
Pollinator alert: Buyers might take home more than a plant if theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re lucky. When we toured the headquarters to look at the sale offerings last week, we spied several caterpillars thatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll one day become black desert swallowtail butterflies and queen butterflies, equents desert milkweed, Asbell said.

Theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll be selling seeds at the sale and some cactus too, Asbell said, such as the lovely silver cholla (Cylindropuntia echinocereus), whose silvery bristles take on an ethereal glow in the setting sun. But Asbell said itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s wrong to think of cactuses as the only plants that grow in the desert. Shrubs actually have a much more important role, she said.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s perfectly acceptable to plant cactus and succulents to preserve water, but we need native shrubs to enrich the environment,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Thereï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a common misperception that the desert is a wasteland, which itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not. Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a functional, thriving ecosystem and a lot of animals and people depend on this ecosystem to remain healthy, so the more we can do to keep these ecosystems intact and restore them or enhance them, the better.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½


Asbell said many customers are urban dwellers who have a second home in the desert and are eager to add native plfferent than in L.A., she said, an everything-you-know-is-wrong lesson she had to learn herself when she left her plant conservation job at the Theodore Payne Foundation in Sun Valley to start the plant conservation program at the land trust in 2016.

For instance, she said, the rule of thumb when planting a tree or shrub around Los Angeles is to make the hole wider than the root ball to give the roots plenty of room to settle in. In the desert, she said, itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s best to keep the hole just big enough for the root ball to fit and no wider.

column6:
The Oakland Police Department is searching for at least two gunmen who fired 30 rounds at an East Oakland high school, injuring six people.

The two with the most serious injuries were listed as  critical but stable at Oaklandï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Highland Hospital, the countyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s main trauma hospital,  while a third victim was listed as  stable, according to Alameda Health System officials.

column1: In groundbreaking plan, California allows affordable housing on some commercial properties
column6:
In a historic deal between affordable housing groups and labor unions, Gov. Gavin Newsom  signed two major bills Wednesday toconvert underutilized and vacant commercial buildings into housing.
Senate Bill 6andAssembly Bill 2011incentivize housing projects in commercial corridors otherwise zoned for large retail and office buildings as a way to help California fill a multimillion-unit shortage in its housing supply. Both bills guarantee union-scale wages and promise an expedited construction process, while keeping development close to city centers to help the state meet its environmental goals and avoid sprawl.
Newsom said the two laws will help California address the stateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½original sinï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ of housing affordability.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It has been a stubborn issue. Decade after decade after decade, just fighting and talking about it and fighting each other in the process,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Newsom said.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I think what makes today a special day is this is a big moment as we begin ... to take responsibnd expect the same applause, but to begin to do something about it,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Newsom said during a  news conference in San Francisco to sign the two proposals and dozens of other measures. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½This is a big package. These bills matter.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Gridlock among several opposing forces in the Capitol ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ where unions, developers and affordable housing groupsregularly stall legislation over disputed labor standardsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ nearly capsized this yearï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s historic deal. The powerful State Building and Construction Trades Council of California backed SB 6, along with builders and business groups, while the California Conference of Carpenters and the Service Employees International Union of California broke from other labor groups to support AB 2011.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Every organization took a position that benefited them the best and decided which bill they wanted to support. And part of the challenge there is that each coalition of people were ready to have the other bill die in order for their bill to be suo (D-Salinas). ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The problem was that you couldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t get to that perfect middle with some of the groups. They just wouldnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t go there.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The two bills offer developers options on projects intended to convert underutilized and vacant commercial spaces such as big-box stores, strip malls and office buildings into much-needed housing.
Despite the energy and effort required to pass the bills, both Caballero and Assemblymember Buffy Wicks, an Oakland Democrat who wrote AB 2011, said theyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½re willing to broker a future deal on similar legislation.
California

ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Today we are taking a monumental step in our efforts to turn our housing crisis in a different direction,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½  Wicks said in a statement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The governorï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s signature on AB 2011 marks a turning point for Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s housing productnger will there be a lack of incentive for workers to join the construction workforce. And, no longer will red tape and bureaucracy prohibit us from building housing in the right locations to address our climate crisis.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Experts say the effect on Californiaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s housing supply could be significant.
Caballero said SB 6 will help rural communities recover from a big chain store exodus that left behind a trail of vacant buildings and parking lots. She sees the new law as a way to produce housing for first-time buyers.
Housing advocates are particularly excited about AB 2011.
An August analysis by UrbanFootprint, a software platform that analyzes city data for urban planners and local governments, found that the new law could produce1.6 million to 2.4 million new homes, depending on market conditions, including hundreds of thousands of affordable units.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½AB 2011 has tremendous potential to unlock ... a ton of land for development that was previously off-limits,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said David Garcia, poleleyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Terner Center for Housing Innovation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a huge deal.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Garcia said he sees both bills as a sign that lawmakers in Sacramento are taking a stronger ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½pro-housing approachï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and are willing to push for the kind of legislation that is notoriously difficult to pass amid interest group infighting.
Ray Pearl, executive director of the California Housing Consortium, one of the co-sponsors of AB 2011, called the measure a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½game changer.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s really unprecedented that we brought together all of those different groups. As you look forward, nothing is ever easy in Sacramento, nor should it be,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Pearl said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½But there are a lot of folks that want similar outcomes. Hopefully, we are going to be able to use this coalition for future efforts.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Erin Lehane, legislative director for the trades council, said SB 6 will provide valuable work to local residents.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½These are opportunities for young people who recks worked together to craft two bills that promised each coalition a slice of the pie.
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½As the clock started ticking down, we both agreed we would make some amendments that would give each one of us what we wanted,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Caballero said, even if that meant ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½everybody was a little bit unhappyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ with the final product.
Housing & Homelessness
When developers build affordable housing in a luxury complex like the Grand LA, the units are added to a regional pool that are rented out by lottery.
The Assembly bill includes a requirement for union-scale wages, along with stringent environmental standards and a mandate that a certain percentage of the units be affordable for low- and extremely low-income residents.
Some projects would be exempt from local governmentsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ discretionary approval process as well as the restrictive California Environmental Quality Act, which has been used as a legal weapon to slow down or even halt housing construction.
The labor requirement ensures that contrfits and union-level pay, so-calledprevailing wages, to all workers, even if some arenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t unionized. Contractors have argued that prevailing-wage requirements drive up costs and housing prices.
The Senateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s version was billed as a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½middle-classï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ housing proposal, and requires the union-scale wages as a minimum labor standard while ensuring that a so-called skilled and trained workforce is used in most situations. The additional regulation guarantees most workers are unionized.
The cautious optimism about future legislative housing agreements could be short-lived, however.
Lehane said the trade unions remain concerned about most residential housing construction projects, especially those not using union workers, because those builders are ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½paying and treating workers unfairly.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I think that is not something that changes overnight,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½As our responsibility, we need to remain ever vigilant to that.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The new laws will go intoires will strain resources. Bringing back every town will only put people in mortal danger once again.
